ground_truth_correlations.description: Progressive HbA1c elevation from 8.2% to 10.8% over 7 months despite medication escalation
Declining renal function with GFR drop from 68 to 48 mL/min and rising creatinine
Persistent fatigue correlating with worsening anemia (Hgb 13.2 to 10.1 g/dL)
No retinal examination performed despite diabetic retinopathy risk and duration of diabetes >10 years

clinical_timeline.chief_complaint: Follow-up for diabetes, feeling more tired lately
clinical_timeline.provider_note_snippet: A1c elevated at 8.2%, adding glipizide to regimen. Discussed diet and exercise. Patient reports difficulty with portion control. RTC 3 months.

clinical_timeline.chief_complaint: Still feeling tired all the time, some tingling in feet
clinical_timeline.provider_note_snippet: Patient reports persistent fatigue and paresthesias in feet. Hemoglobin slightly down at 12.4. B12 and folate normal. Starting gabapentin 300mg for neuropathy. Increased glipizide dose.

clinical_timeline.chief_complaint: Diabetes check, foot numbness not much better

dose_changed: Metformin increased to 1000mg three times daily

clinical_timeline.provider_note_snippet: A1c worsened to 9.1% despite medication increases. Creatinine now 1.5, GFR 58 - concerning for progressive nephropathy. Hemoglobin trending down. Referred to nephrology. Discussed insulin initiation if A1c not improved at next visit.

clinical_timeline.chief_complaint: Fatigue getting worse, some swelling in ankles
clinical_timeline.provider_note_snippet: Hemoglobin continues to decline, now 10.8. Ferritin low at 72. Started iron supplementation. Patient missed nephrology appointment - will reschedule. Fatigue likely related to anemia and poor glucose control. Weight gain of 4 lbs, some pedal edema noted.

clinical_timeline.chief_complaint: Diabetes follow-up, tired all the time, can barely get through work day
clinical_timeline.provider_note_snippet: A1c now 10.2% - significantly elevated. Renal function worsening with GFR 52, creatinine 1.7. Anemia persistent despite iron supplementation. Starting basal insulin. Long discussion about medication adherence - patient reports financial barriers to medications and healthy food. Connected with social work.

clinical_timeline.chief_complaint: Insulin follow-up, still very fatigued

dose_changed: Insulin glargine increased to 20 units at bedtime

clinical_timeline.provider_note_snippet: Diabetes control continues to deteriorate despite insulin initiation - A1c 10.8%. Patient admits not taking insulin consistently due to cost. GFR now 48, concerning for progression to Stage 3b CKD. Anemia worsening. NO RETINAL EXAM DOCUMENTED IN 18+ MONTHS - critical gap. Discussed urgent need for ophthalmology. Increased insulin dose and added amlodipine for BP control.

expected_llm_challenges: Distinguishing medication non-adherence from treatment resistance
Connecting multiple organ system complications to underlying diabetes
Recognizing the interaction between anemia and fatigue in context of CKD
Detecting the critical care gap (missed retinal exam) amidst multiple other issues
Understanding social determinants (food insecurity, medication costs) as contributors to poor control
evaluation_notes: This case tests ability to: (1) track multiple lab trends simultaneously, (2) recognize progressive multi-organ diabetic complications, (3) identify medication non-response patterns, (4) detect preventive care gaps, and (5) incorporate social determinants into clinical reasoning. The LLM should flag the missing ophthalmology referral as high priority given duration and severity of diabetes.

ground_truth_correlations.description: Rapid weight gain (12 lbs in 10 days) correlating with worsening dyspnea and edema in CHF patient
Dramatically elevated BNP from baseline 450 to 2800 pg/mL indicating acute decompensated heart failure
Progressive orthopnea and paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea signaling volume overload
Inadequate diuretic dosing for acute volume overload requiring IV diuretics and hospitalization

clinical_timeline.chief_complaint: Heart failure follow-up, doing well

active_chronic: Heart failure with reduced ejection fraction, EF 30% (I50.22)
Coronary artery disease, history of CABG 2020 (I25.10, Z95.1)

clinical_timeline.provider_note_snippet: Stable CHF visit. EF 30% on last echo 3 months ago. Patient doing well on GDMT (guideline-directed medical therapy). No dyspnea at rest, able to walk 2 blocks without symptoms. Dry weight 152 lbs. No edema on exam. Lungs clear. JVP not elevated. BNP 450 (stable from prior). Continue current medications. Reinforced daily weights and low-sodium diet.

clinical_timeline.chief_complaint: Noticed some ankle swelling past few days, feeling a bit more winded

active_chronic: Heart failure with reduced ejection fraction, EF 30% (I50.22)
Coronary artery disease, history of CABG 2020 (I25.10, Z95.1)

clinical_timeline.provider_note_snippet: Patient with 5 lb weight gain from dry weight (152 to 157 lbs). Reports increased ankle swelling and mild dyspnea with usual activities. 1+ pitting edema bilateral ankles. Lungs still clear. Patient admits eating more salty foods at family gathering last weekend. Increased furosemide to 60mg daily. Reinforced strict low-sodium diet. Daily weights. RTC if weight increases further or dyspnea worsens.

clinical_timeline.chief_complaint: Much more short of breath, can't sleep lying flat, legs very swollen

started: Furosemide 80mg IV x1 dose given in urgent care
dose_changed: Furosemide increased to 80mg PO twice daily

active_chronic: Heart failure with reduced ejection fraction, EF 30% (I50.22)
Coronary artery disease, history of CABG 2020 (I25.10, Z95.1)

procedures_ordered: Chest X-ray - shows pulmonary edema, cardiomegaly
clinical_timeline.provider_note_snippet: ACUTE CHF EXACERBATION. Patient with 12 lb weight gain in 10 days (152 to 164 lbs). Significant respiratory distress with orthopnea (sleeps on 3 pillows now vs usual 1), PND x3 nights. 3+ pitting edema to knees bilaterally. Crackles bilateral bases. JVP elevated to 12cm. SpO2 91% on room air. CXR shows pulmonary edema. Patient admits dietary indiscretion - eating restaurant meals daily. Given furosemide 80mg IV with good response (urinated 800cc in 2 hours). Increased PO furosemide to 80mg BID. Patient stable for outpatient management but needs close follow-up. If no improvement in 24-48 hours, will need hospital admission.

clinical_timeline.chief_complaint: Worse shortness of breath, can't breathe lying down at all, coughing up pink frothy sputum

active_chronic: Heart failure with reduced ejection fraction, EF 30% (I50.22)
Coronary artery disease, history of CABG 2020 (I25.10, Z95.1)
new_acute: Acute decompensated heart failure with pulmonary edema (I50.23)

procedures_ordered: Chest X-ray - severe pulmonary edema, bilateral pleural effusions
Echo - EF 25% (decreased from 30%), severe volume overload
clinical_timeline.provider_note_snippet: SEVERE ACUTE DECOMPENSATED HEART FAILURE. Patient failed outpatient diuresis, continued to gain weight (now 166 lbs, 14 lbs above dry weight). Presenting with acute pulmonary edema - pink frothy sputum, severe respiratory distress, SpO2 86% on room air. Tachypneic at 28/min, tachycardic to 102. Diffuse crackles throughout lung fields, large pleural effusions on CXR. JVP >15cm. 3+ edema to thighs. BNP critically elevated at 2800 (baseline 450). Echo shows EF declined to 25%, severe volume overload. Cardiorenal syndrome developing (Cr 1.7, Na 133). Started on BiPAP with improvement in work of breathing. IV furosemide 80mg Q8H + metolazone 5mg for aggressive diuresis. ADMITTED TO CCU. Patient needs intensive monitoring, possible ultrafiltration if diuretics inadequate.

clinical_timeline.chief_complaint: Follow-up after hospital discharge, breathing much better now

active_chronic: Heart failure with reduced ejection fraction, EF 25% (I50.22)
Coronary artery disease, history of CABG 2020 (I25.10, Z95.1)

procedures_ordered: Weekly weights to clinic for 1 month
Home health nursing for medication reconciliation and education
clinical_timeline.provider_note_snippet: Post-discharge follow-up after 7-day CCU admission. Patient received aggressive IV diuresis (total net negative 18 liters), ultimately required single session of ultrafiltration. Discharged on increased diuretic regimen. Currently at NEW dry weight of 150 lbs (2 lbs below previous dry weight of 152). No dyspnea at rest, no orthopnea. Trace edema only. Lungs clear. EF declined from 30% to 25% on discharge echo - concerning progression. Long discussion about dietary sodium restriction, medication adherence, and daily weight monitoring. Patient very motivated after this hospitalization. Enrolled in home health for close monitoring and education. Weekly weight checks in clinic x1 month. Considering ICD/CRT evaluation given EF decline.

expected_llm_challenges: Recognizing rapid weight gain as the critical early warning sign of CHF decompensation
Connecting orthopnea and PND with volume overload before overt pulmonary edema
Understanding the significance of BNP elevation from 450 to 2800 pg/mL
Distinguishing inadequate outpatient diuresis from true diuretic resistance
Recognizing cardiorenal syndrome (worsening kidney function despite diuresis need)
Understanding the escalation from oral to IV diuretics to ultrafiltration
evaluation_notes: This case tests ability to: (1) recognize acute-on-chronic heart failure exacerbation through weight and symptom tracking, (2) understand the clinical significance of orthopnea, PND, and progressive edema, (3) correlate laboratory values (BNP, creatinine) with clinical deterioration, (4) recognize treatment failure requiring escalation of care, (5) understand cardiorenal syndrome complicating diuresis, and (6) appreciate the importance of medication adherence and dietary factors in CHF management. The LLM should flag early warning signs at V2 with 5 lb weight gain, recognize acute decompensation by V3, identify critical status requiring hospitalization at V4, and understand the long-term implications of EF decline by V5.

ground_truth_correlations.description: Progressive unintentional weight loss (22 lbs over 6 months) without clear benign etiology
Progressive iron deficiency anemia despite supplementation, concerning for GI blood loss
Intermittent abdominal pain and change in bowel habits persisting across multiple visits
Delayed colonoscopy despite red flag symptoms (weight loss, anemia, age >70, bowel changes) - 4+ month delay

clinical_timeline.chief_complaint: Annual physical, also noticed losing some weight without trying
clinical_timeline.provider_note_snippet: Annual physical. Patient reports 8 lb unintentional weight loss over past 3 months (was 190 lbs, now 182 lbs). Attributes to 'eating less' but no clear reason. Hemoglobin slightly low at 12.8, ferritin low at 38 suggesting iron deficiency. No obvious bleeding source. Stool guaiac ordered. Started iron supplementation. Patient last colonoscopy was 12 years ago (age 59) - overdue for screening. Will schedule if stool guaiac positive.

clinical_timeline.chief_complaint: Follow-up on weight loss and anemia, now having some belly discomfort
clinical_timeline.provider_note_snippet: Patient with continued weight loss - now down to 178 lbs (12 lbs total over 4 months). Hemoglobin declining despite iron supplementation (12.8 to 12.2). Ferritin minimally improved. Stool guaiac was negative. Now reports vague intermittent lower abdominal cramping and notes stools sometimes harder to pass. B12 and folate normal. Referred for upper endoscopy to evaluate for gastric source of bleeding/malabsorption. Patient hesitant about colonoscopy, wants to 'see what EGD shows first.'

clinical_timeline.chief_complaint: EGD results follow-up, weight still dropping, constipation worse
clinical_timeline.provider_note_snippet: EGD results: mild gastritis, no ulcers, biopsies benign. This does NOT explain progressive weight loss and anemia. Patient now down 18 lbs total (190 to 172 lbs over 5 months). Hemoglobin continues to decline (11.4). Ferritin not improving despite iron therapy. New complaints of worsening constipation and crampy abdominal pain. CRP and ESR elevated suggesting inflammation. NEED COLONOSCOPY - this could be colon cancer, IBD, or other colonic pathology. Strongly recommended colonoscopy. Patient agrees but wants to wait until after daughter's wedding in 6 weeks.

clinical_timeline.chief_complaint: Weight loss continues, very fatigued, noticed blood on toilet paper few times
procedures_ordered: Colonoscopy URGENT - called GI to expedite
clinical_timeline.provider_note_snippet: ALARMING PROGRESSION. Patient now 22 lbs below baseline weight (190 to 168 lbs over 6 months). Hemoglobin 10.2 - moderate anemia worsening despite iron. Now reports visible blood on toilet paper with bowel movements. Severe fatigue limiting activities. Platelets elevated at 445 (reactive thrombocytosis - concerning for malignancy). CRP and ESR markedly elevated. This is RED FLAG constellation: age >70 + progressive weight loss + worsening anemia + GI bleeding + inflammatory markers. HIGH SUSPICION FOR COLORECTAL CANCER. Called GI to expedite colonoscopy - scheduled for next week. Ordered CEA tumor marker.

clinical_timeline.chief_complaint: Colonoscopy results discussion

new_acute: Adenocarcinoma of sigmoid colon, Stage II (C18.7)

clinical_timeline.provider_note_snippet: COLONOSCOPY RESULTS: Large, partially obstructing mass in sigmoid colon (5cm). Biopsies confirm moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma. CEA elevated at 42 ng/mL (normal <5). This explains entire clinical picture - progressive weight loss, iron deficiency anemia, bowel changes, bleeding, inflammatory markers. CT staging pending but no obvious metastases on initial imaging. Likely Stage II or III. Referred urgently to surgical oncology for resection. Patient and family devastated but also relieved to have diagnosis. In retrospect, colonoscopy should have been done 4-5 months ago when red flags first appeared. Delay may have allowed progression. Important lesson about acting quickly on alarm symptoms.

expected_llm_challenges: Recognizing the constellation of alarm symptoms (weight loss + anemia + age >70) early in the timeline
Understanding that negative stool guaiac does NOT rule out GI malignancy
Identifying the pattern of progressive anemia despite iron supplementation as highly concerning
Recognizing reactive thrombocytosis and elevated inflammatory markers as potential cancer signals
Understanding the critical delay in performing colonoscopy despite multiple red flags
Connecting seemingly disparate symptoms (weight loss, anemia, constipation, fatigue) to a unifying diagnosis
evaluation_notes: This case tests ability to: (1) recognize occult cancer presentation through progressive symptoms over time, (2) identify alarm symptoms requiring urgent investigation, (3) understand that normal or minimally helpful initial tests do not exclude serious pathology, (4) track multiple converging clinical indicators (weight loss, anemia, bleeding, inflammatory markers), (5) recognize critical diagnostic delays as care gaps, and (6) appreciate the urgency needed when multiple red flags are present. The LLM should flag concern by V1-V2 with weight loss and anemia in elderly patient, recognize high suspicion for malignancy by V3 with progressive symptoms and normal EGD, identify critical urgency by V4 with overt bleeding and severe anemia, and understand that the 4-5 month delay to colonoscopy was a significant care gap that may have affected outcomes.

archetype: Anticoagulation failure leading to preventable stroke
chief_complaint: Palpitations, irregular heartbeat, fatigue x3 weeks

ground_truth_correlations.description: New-onset atrial fibrillation with high stroke risk requiring anticoagulation
Acute ischemic stroke while on inadequate anticoagulation demonstrating importance of INR monitoring
Transition from warfarin to DOAC with improved anticoagulation stability and quality of life
Successful rate control and anticoagulation management preventing recurrent stroke

clinical_timeline.chief_complaint: Palpitations, irregular heartbeat, fatigue x3 weeks
clinical_timeline.provider_note_snippet: 74F retired teacher presents with 3-week history of palpitations, sensation of 'irregular heartbeat,' and increased fatigue. SYMPTOM DETAILS: Palpitations intermittent but occurring daily, lasting minutes to hours. Describes heart as 'fluttering' or 'racing.' Associated with mild lightheadedness but no syncope, no chest pain, no dyspnea at rest (mild dyspnea with exertion - new). Fatigue more pronounced - 'don't have energy I used to.' PAST MEDICAL HISTORY: Hypertension x 15 years, controlled on amlodipine. Hypothyroidism x 10 years on levothyroxine. Hyperlipidemia on statin. Stage 3a CKD (baseline creatinine 1.0, GFR 58). History of amiodarone intolerance in 2021 (developed thyroid toxicity and interstitial lung disease, discontinued after 6 months). No prior cardiac history - no MI, no heart failure, no valvular disease. SOCIAL HISTORY: Retired elementary school teacher. Widowed 5 years ago. Lives alone in apartment, 2 adult children nearby (daughter age 48, son age 45). Independent with ADLs. Never smoker, no alcohol. PHYSICAL EXAM: Alert, well-appearing elderly Asian female. BP 142/86, HR 115 (tachycardic), irregularly irregular rhythm (classic for AFib). No JVP elevation. Lungs clear. Cardiac: Irregularly irregular rhythm, no murmurs, no S3/S4. Abdomen soft. Extremities: No edema. Neurologic: Grossly intact. ECG (performed in office): ATRIAL FIBRILLATION with rapid ventricular response, rate 110-120 bpm, No P waves visible, irregularly irregular R-R intervals, No acute ST-T changes, QRS narrow. ASSESSMENT: NEW-ONSET ATRIAL FIBRILLATION. This is most common sustained arrhythmia, especially in elderly. Affects 10-15% of people >80 years old. Patient is 74 with multiple risk factors: age, hypertension, possible structural heart disease (need echo). STROKE RISK ASSESSMENT - CHA2DS2-VASc SCORE: C - Congestive heart failure: 0 (no HF history, but need echo) H - Hypertension: 1 (yes, on medication) A - Age 75: 0 (age 74, just under cutoff) D - Diabetes: 0 (no diabetes) S - Prior Stroke/TIA: 0 (no prior stroke) V - Vascular disease: 0 (no CAD/PAD/aortic disease) A - Age 65-74: 1 (yes) Sc - Sex category (female): 1 (yes) TOTAL CHA2DS2-VASc: 3 points = HIGH STROKE RISK (4-6% annual stroke risk without anticoagulation). ANTICOAGULATION STRONGLY RECOMMENDED (reduces stroke risk by ~60-70%). MANAGEMENT PLAN: (1) RATE CONTROL: Started metoprolol 25mg BID to slow heart rate (target <110 bpm at rest). (2) RHYTHM vs RATE CONTROL: Will defer to cardiology, but given age and likely will pursue rate control strategy (maintain AFib, control rate) rather than rhythm control (cardioversion, antiarrhythmic drugs). Rhythm control doesn't improve outcomes in elderly with persistent AFib, and patient cannot take amiodarone (prior toxicity). (3) ANTICOAGULATION: Patient requires anticoagulation given CHA2DS2-VASc 3. Options: Warfarin (vitamin K antagonist, requires INR monitoring), DOACs (direct oral anticoagulants - apixaban, rivaroxaban, edoxaban, dabigatran - no monitoring required, but more expensive). Will discuss with cardiology and patient. Patient has Medicare Part D but concerned about medication costs. (4) ECHOCARDIOGRAM: Need to assess LV function, valvular disease, atrial size, rule out structural abnormalities. (5) THYROID CHECK: TSH normal (2.8), so AFib not from hyperthyroidism. Patient explained: Atrial fibrillation means top chambers of heart quivering instead of beating normally. Most concerning risk is STROKE - blood can pool in atria and form clots, clots can travel to brain. MUST have anticoagulation (blood thinner) to prevent stroke. Will need this lifelong. Patient anxious about 'blood thinners' - worried about bleeding. Explained benefits outweigh risks given high stroke risk. Cardiology referral placed, appointment in 2 weeks.

social_history_updates.living_situation: Lives alone, widowed 5 years, 2 adult children nearby
social_history_updates.insurance: Medicare Part A+B, Part D prescription coverage with co-pays
social_history_updates.support: Daughter visits weekly, son helps with errands

clinical_timeline.chief_complaint: New-onset atrial fibrillation, anticoagulation planning
procedures_ordered: INR monitoring (check in 5 days, then weekly until therapeutic, then monthly)
clinical_timeline.provider_note_snippet: CARDIOLOGY CONSULTATION for new-onset AFib, anticoagulation decision. ECHOCARDIOGRAM RESULTS (2/28): LV size normal, LV function normal (EF 60-65%), No regional wall motion abnormalities, Mild left atrial enlargement (LA diameter 4.2cm), Mild mitral regurgitation (trace-mild), No other valvular disease, No LV thrombus, No pericardial effusion. INTERPRETATION: Structurally normal heart except mild LA enlargement (consistent with AFib). Normal LV function. HOLTER MONITOR (48 hours, 2/25-2/27): Atrial fibrillation throughout entire recording (persistent AFib, not paroxysmal). Average heart rate 85 bpm (improved on metoprolol from 115 bpm). Maximum heart rate 125 bpm. Minimum heart rate 62 bpm. No significant pauses. ASSESSMENT: PERSISTENT ATRIAL FIBRILLATION. Likely has been in AFib longer than 3 weeks (patient may not have noticed initially). With persistent AFib and age 74, RATE CONTROL strategy is appropriate (not pursuing rhythm control/cardioversion). RATE CONTROL: Metoprolol 25mg BID providing adequate rate control (HR 92 at rest, average 85 on Holter). Will continue current dose. Goal <110 bpm at rest (lenient rate control, appropriate for elderly). ANTICOAGULATION DECISION: CHA2DS2-VASc 3 = MUST anticoagulate. BLEEDING RISK ASSESSMENT - HAS-BLED SCORE: H - Hypertension: 1 (yes) A - Abnormal renal/liver function: 0 (GFR 58, mild CKD but not dialysis; liver function normal) S - Stroke: 0 (no prior stroke) B - Bleeding: 0 (no prior bleeding) L - Labile INR: 0 (not on warfarin yet) E - Elderly (>65): 1 (age 74) D - Drugs/alcohol: 0 (no NSAIDs, no alcohol) HAS-BLED: 2 = MODERATE bleeding risk (but stroke risk still outweighs bleeding risk, anticoagulation indicated). WARFARIN vs DOAC DISCUSSION: DOACs (apixaban, rivaroxaban, edoxaban): Pros: No INR monitoring, more stable anticoagulation, lower intracranial bleeding risk, fewer drug/food interactions. Cons: More expensive ($400-600/month), no reversal agent for some (though now available for some DOACs), require good renal function (patient has GFR 58 - acceptable for most DOACs with dose adjustment). Warfarin: Pros: Inexpensive ($4-10/month generic), long track record, reversible with vitamin K/FFP, Medicare covers. Cons: Requires frequent INR monitoring (blood draws), many drug and food interactions (vitamin K in greens), narrow therapeutic window, variable dosing. PATIENT PREFERENCE: Patient chose WARFARIN primarily for cost reasons. On fixed income (Social Security + small pension), concerned about DOAC co-pays even with Medicare Part D ($50-100/month co-pay). Warfarin essentially free with Medicare. WARFARIN INITIATION: Starting dose 5mg daily (standard for elderly Asian female - typically require lower doses). INR goal 2-3 (standard for AFib). INR monitoring: Check in 5 days, then adjust dose, then weekly until stable in therapeutic range x2 weeks, then every 2 weeks x1 month, then monthly if stable. WARFARIN EDUCATION: Must take same time daily, avoid large fluctuations in vitamin K intake (can eat greens but be consistent), many drug interactions (told to check before starting any new medications), watch for bleeding signs (easy bruising, blood in urine/stool, unusual bleeding). Patient understanding but appears anxious about monitoring requirements. Daughter will help with appointments. Fall risk assessment: Patient stable on feet, no fall history, but at age 74 with anticoagulation, fall with head trauma could be catastrophic (intracranial hemorrhage). Educated on fall prevention. PROGNOSIS: With rate control and anticoagulation, excellent prognosis. Stroke risk reduced from 4-6%/year to <1%/year with warfarin. Quality of life should improve as heart rate controlled and symptoms diminish.
clinical_timeline.patient_reported_adherence: good - daughter helping with medication management and appointment scheduling

social_history_updates.finances: On fixed income (Social Security + pension), medication costs a concern

clinical_timeline.chief_complaint: Sudden onset right arm weakness, difficulty speaking x2 hours

new_acute: Acute ischemic stroke, left MCA territory (I63.512)

clinical_timeline.provider_note_snippet: 74F with known AFib on warfarin presents via EMS with ACUTE STROKE. ONSET: 12:15pm today (arrived ED 2:05pm = 1 hour 50 minutes from symptom onset). Patient was at home, daughter visiting for lunch. At 12:15pm, patient suddenly unable to lift right arm, face drooping on right side, speech garbled. Daughter called 911 immediately. LAST KNOWN WELL: 12:15pm today. SYMPTOMS: Right arm weakness (unable to lift against gravity), Right facial droop, Expressive aphasia (difficulty speaking, word-finding difficulty), Alert and following commands with left arm. NO seizure activity, NO loss of consciousness, NO headache. NIHSS (NIH Stroke Scale): 8 points (moderate stroke) - Right arm: 3 (drift, cannot lift), Right face: 2 (partial paralysis), Language: 2 (aphasia, some meaningful speech), Sensory: 1 (mild sensory loss right side). PAST MEDICAL HISTORY: ATRIAL FIBRILLATION - diagnosed 2 months ago, on warfarin for stroke prevention. INR goal 2-3. Last INR check 2 weeks ago was 2.1 (therapeutic). Patient reports taking warfarin daily as prescribed. No recent medication changes, no dietary changes, no new medications. PHYSICAL EXAM: Alert, oriented to self and place (not to time), following commands. BP 168/92 (hypertensive, common in acute stroke). HR 98, irregularly irregular (AFib). Neurologic: Right facial droop, right arm 1/5 strength (no movement against gravity), right leg 3/5 strength, expressive aphasia (understands but cannot speak fluently). CT HEAD NON-CONTRAST (2:15pm): NO acute hemorrhage, NO large territorial infarct (early ischemic changes not always visible on CT), NO mass effect, NO midline shift. Negative CT does NOT rule out acute ischemic stroke. CT ANGIOGRAPHY: Left middle cerebral artery (MCA) M2 segment occlusion. Proximal vessels patent. INR: 1.4 (SUBTHERAPEUTIC - goal 2-3). Patient supposedly taking warfarin daily. This is WARFARIN FAILURE or NON-ADHERENCE or interaction. ASSESSMENT: ACUTE ISCHEMIC STROKE - LEFT MCA TERRITORY from CARDIOEMBOLIC source (AFib with inadequate anticoagulation). This is exactly what we try to prevent with anticoagulation. INR 1.4 is subtherapeutic - patient NOT adequately anticoagulated despite reported adherence. THROMBOLYSIS CONSIDERATION: Patient within 4.5-hour window for tPA (tissue plasminogen activator - clot-busting drug). However, INR 1.4 and on warfarin = RELATIVE CONTRAINDICATION. Neurology consulted - decision: Given small vessel occlusion (M2, not M1), moderate deficit (NIHSS 8), and risk of hemorrhagic transformation with warfarin on board, will NOT give tPA. Will pursue supportive care. THROMBECTOMY CONSIDERATION: M2 occlusion is small for mechanical thrombectomy. Typically done for large vessel occlusion (M1, ICA, basilar). Interventional neuro consulted - patient NOT candidate for thrombectomy given small vessel and moderate deficit. MANAGEMENT: Supportive care, blood pressure management (permissive hypertension in acute stroke to maintain penumbra perfusion - goal SBP 140-180), monitor for hemorrhagic transformation, ASA 325mg given (antiplatelet), warfarin held acutely (will resume in 24-48 hours once hemorrhage ruled out on repeat imaging), neurology admission. MRI BRAIN (4/22 evening): Acute infarct left MCA territory (insular cortex, inferior frontal gyrus), restricted diffusion on DWI, approximately 2cm territory, No hemorrhage. INTERPRETATION: Small cortical infarct from left MCA M2 branch occlusion. Cardioembolic stroke from AFib. PATIENT/FAMILY DISCUSSION: Daughter devastated. 'But she was taking her blood thinner! How did this happen?' Reviewed INR 1.4 (subtherapeutic). Possible explanations: (1) NON-ADHERENCE - patient missing doses (possible - elderly, lives alone, may forget), (2) DRUG INTERACTION - new medication or supplement interfering with warfarin (patient denies), (3) DIETARY CHANGES - increased vitamin K intake (patient denies), (4) WARFARIN VARIABILITY - INR can fluctuate even with perfect adherence. Daughter feels guilty - 'I should have been checking on her medications more carefully.' Explained stroke risk remains even with anticoagulation (warfarin reduces risk 60-70%, but not 100%). However, subtherapeutic INR increases risk substantially.
clinical_timeline.patient_reported_adherence: patient states taking warfarin daily, but INR subtherapeutic - suggests non-adherence or interaction

social_history_updates.functional_status: Baseline independent, now with right hemiparesis and aphasia

clinical_timeline.chief_complaint: Stroke service Day 6, preparing for acute rehab discharge

continued: Atorvastatin increased to 80mg daily (high-intensity statin post-stroke)
stopped: Aspirin discontinued after 24 hours (now on apixaban)

new_acute: Acute ischemic stroke, left MCA territory, with residual deficits (I63.512)

clinical_timeline.provider_note_snippet: STROKE DAY 6 - PREPARING FOR REHAB DISCHARGE. CLINICAL COURSE: Patient admitted 4/22 with left MCA stroke. Initial NIHSS 8 (moderate). Received supportive care, no tPA or thrombectomy. Warfarin restarted 4/24 (48 hours post-stroke, after repeat CT showed no hemorrhage). MRI (4/23): Confirmed small cortical infarct, no hemorrhagic transformation. CURRENT NEUROLOGIC STATUS: Significant improvement over 6 days. Right arm: 3/5 strength (was 1/5 on admission) - can lift against gravity, some resistance. Right leg: 4/5 strength (was 3/5) - nearly normal. Facial droop: Minimal residual weakness. Aphasia: Improved - speaking in short sentences, some word-finding difficulty but communicating needs. NIHSS now 4 (mild stroke) - improved from 8. FUNCTIONAL STATUS: Requires assistance with ADLs (dressing, bathing due to right arm weakness). Can ambulate with walker and supervision. Swallowing evaluation: Passed - tolerating regular diet. THERAPY ASSESSMENTS: Physical therapy: Recommends acute inpatient rehab - patient has rehab potential, motivated, medically stable. Speech therapy: Recommends continued intensive speech therapy for aphasia. Occupational therapy: Needs ADL retraining with dominant right hand weakness. ANTICOAGULATION CHANGE - WARFARIN TO DOAC: DISCUSSION: Patient's stroke occurred while on warfarin with SUBTHERAPEUTIC INR (1.4). Reviewed medication adherence with patient and daughter. Patient admits sometimes forgets whether she took warfarin (lives alone, no pill organizer, relies on memory). Daughter states she only checks medications weekly, did not realize mother was missing doses. INR HISTORY REVIEW: 3/10: INR 2.2 (therapeutic), 3/24: INR 2.1 (therapeutic), 4/8: INR 1.8 (low-therapeutic), 4/22: INR 1.4 (subtherapeutic, day of stroke). PATTERN: INR trending down despite reported adherence - suggests intermittent non-adherence. DECISION: SWITCH FROM WARFARIN TO DOAC (apixaban). Rationale: (1) No INR monitoring required - removes burden of frequent blood draws, (2) More predictable anticoagulation - less variable response, (3) Twice-daily dosing may help with adherence (patient remembers morning/evening pills better than once-daily), (4) Lower intracranial hemorrhage risk if future falls. COST DISCUSSION: Major barrier previously was cost. However, post-stroke, daughter willing to help cover co-pays. Medicare Part D covers DOACs with typical co-pay $50-100/month. Daughter will pay co-pay difference. Additionally, manufacturer assistance program may reduce cost. APIXABAN DOSING: Standard dose 5mg BID. (Would use 2.5mg BID reduced dose if met 2 of 3 criteria: age 80, weight 60kg, creatinine 1.5. Patient is 74yo, 127 lbs (58kg), creatinine 1.0 = meets 1 criterion only, so STANDARD dose 5mg BID appropriate). GFR 58 = safe for apixaban (can use down to GFR 15). Overlap: Warfarin discontinued, apixaban started immediately (no bridging needed). INR will decline over next few days as warfarin wears off. DISCHARGE PLAN: ACUTE INPATIENT REHABILITATION for 2-3 weeks. Intensive therapy (3 hours/day, 5-6 days/week). Goal: Maximize functional recovery, improve right arm function, improve speech, train for ADL independence. After rehab: Home with home health services (PT, OT, speech therapy continuation). May need some assistance - daughter plans to increase visits to daily initially, considering home health aide. SECONDARY STROKE PREVENTION: (1) ANTICOAGULATION: Apixaban 5mg BID lifelong (AFib stroke prevention). (2) BLOOD PRESSURE: Continue antihypertensives, goal <140/90 post-stroke. (3) HIGH-INTENSITY STATIN: Atorvastatin increased from 20mg to 80mg (reduces recurrent stroke risk even with cardioembolic stroke). (4) RATE CONTROL: Continue metoprolol for AFib. PROGNOSIS: Favorable. Young stroke (age 74, relatively young for stroke patients), small infarct, significant early improvement (NIHSS 84 in 6 days), motivated patient, good family support. Expect continued recovery over 3-6 months. May recover near-complete function, though some residual aphasia and right hand fine motor deficits likely. Key is preventing RECURRENT stroke - with adequate anticoagulation on DOAC, risk substantially reduced.

clinical_timeline.provider_note_snippet: POST-STROKE 4 WEEKS - CARDIOLOGY FOLLOW-UP. Patient completed 3 weeks acute inpatient rehabilitation (4/28-5/18), discharged home 2 days ago with home health services. REHABILITATION OUTCOMES: Excellent progress. Right arm strength: 4+/5 (nearly normal, can perform most tasks). Right leg strength: 5/5 (normal). Gait: Independent with cane (no longer needs walker). Speech: Mild residual word-finding difficulty but functional communication. ADLs: Independent with dressing, bathing (uses adaptive equipment). Cooking: Independent with supervision initially. FIM score improved from 68 (admission rehab) to 105 (discharge rehab) = significant functional gain. CURRENT SYMPTOMS: Patient reports feeling 'much better.' No palpitations (AFib still present but rate controlled, asymptomatic). No chest pain, no dyspnea. No neurologic symptoms. No falls. PHYSICAL EXAM: Alert, oriented x3. Speech fluent with occasional word-finding pauses. BP 138/80 (well-controlled), HR 84 irregularly irregular (AFib). Right arm: Minimal residual weakness. Gait: Steady with cane. APIXABAN TOLERANCE: Patient tolerating apixaban 5mg BID well. NO bleeding complications - no bruising, no blood in urine/stool, no gum bleeding, no nosebleeds. Daughter managing medications - using pill organizer with AM/PM compartments. Patient takes medications at 8am and 8pm daily. Daughter checks pill box daily via phone video call. MUCH better adherence than with warfarin. ADHERENCE DISCUSSION: Daughter reports patient taking ALL doses of apixaban without missing. Using smartphone alarm reminders. Daughter states 'this is so much easier than warfarin - no blood draws, no clinic visits, no worrying about what she eats.' Patient agrees: 'I feel more confident now. I don't have to remember if I took my pill - I just check the box. And no more needles every week.' RENAL FUNCTION: Stable GFR 58 (unchanged from baseline). Important to monitor with DOAC - if GFR drops <30, would need dose adjustment or switch to warfarin. Will check every 6 months. BLEEDING RISK MONITORING: No signs of bleeding currently. Educated on warning signs: dark/tarry stools, blood in urine, excessive bruising, severe headache, prolonged bleeding from cuts. Fall prevention emphasized - patient using cane, home safety evaluation completed by OT (removed throw rugs, installed grab bars). RATE CONTROL: HR 84 at rest (goal <110), well-controlled on metoprolol 25mg BID. Patient asymptomatic from AFib. Will continue current dose. STROKE PREVENTION: This is why we're here. Patient had stroke 4 weeks ago due to inadequate anticoagulation on warfarin. Now on apixaban with better adherence. Apixaban reduces stroke risk ~60-70% compared to no anticoagulation. With proper adherence, patient's stroke risk now <1%/year (compared to 4-6%/year without anticoagulation). PATIENT PERSPECTIVE: Patient tearful during visit. 'The stroke was terrifying. I couldn't talk, couldn't move my arm. I thought my life was over. I'm so grateful I recovered. I will never miss my blood thinner again. Never.' Daughter also emotional: 'I feel responsible - I should have been monitoring her medications better. Now I check every single day. I won't let this happen again.' PROGNOSIS: Excellent. Patient recovered well from stroke, on appropriate anticoagulation with good adherence, rate controlled, all risk factors managed. Risk of recurrent stroke now very low with adherence to apixaban. Patient may live many more years with good quality of life if continues current management.

clinical_timeline.provider_note_snippet: POST-STROKE 2 MONTHS - NEUROLOGY FOLLOW-UP. NEUROLOGIC EXAMINATION: Mental status: Alert, oriented x3, follows complex commands. Speech: Fluent conversational speech, minimal word-finding difficulty (significant improvement from initial moderate aphasia). Able to name objects, repeat phrases, follow 3-step commands. Cranial nerves: Right facial weakness resolved (was present initially). Motor: Right upper extremity 5/5 strength all muscle groups (full recovery from initial 1/5), Right lower extremity 5/5 strength (full recovery), Left side 5/5 strength. Sensation: Intact to light touch, pinprick bilateral. Coordination: Finger-to-nose, heel-to-shin intact bilaterally. Gait: Normal gait without assistive device (patient brought cane but not using during exam). FUNCTIONAL STATUS: Patient reports 'back to normal' for most activities. Independent with all ADLs, cooking, light housework. Driving: Not yet resumed - will need driving evaluation (occupational therapy) given history of stroke. Patient cautious about driving, 'don't want to hurt anyone.' Social activities: Resumed church attendance, seeing friends, daughter visits 2-3x/week now (decreased from daily). Reading: Back to reading books (had difficulty initially with focus/fatigue). RESIDUAL DEFICITS: Minimal. Occasional word-finding difficulty (anomia) - notices when trying to recall names or specific words, usually can circumlocute. Mild fine motor deficit right hand - difficulty with small buttons, threading needles (not functionally limiting). Fatigue: More fatigued than pre-stroke, needs afternoon rest (common post-stroke, improves over time). STROKE RECOVERY TIMELINE: Patient is 2 months post-stroke. Most recovery occurs in first 3-6 months. Patient has recovered remarkably well - NIHSS went from 8 (moderate) acutely to ~1 (minimal residual deficit) now. This is EXCELLENT outcome. Small cortical stroke + young age (74) + intensive rehab = good recovery potential, which patient achieved. SECONDARY PREVENTION: Anticoagulation: Apixaban 5mg BID - excellent adherence per patient and daughter. No bleeding complications. Blood pressure: Well-controlled <140/90. Statin: High-intensity, appropriate. Rate control: Adequate. Lifestyle: Patient walking daily 20-30 minutes, eating heart-healthy diet. RECURRENT STROKE RISK: With proper anticoagulation (apixaban), blood pressure control, statin, patient's annual stroke risk now <1%. Without anticoagulation, risk would be 4-6%/year. Critical that patient continues apixaban LIFELONG. Explained that stopping anticoagulation would put her at high risk for another stroke, which might be more severe/disabling. Patient understanding: 'I will take this medication forever. I never want to go through that again.' PROGNOSIS: Excellent. Patient has achieved near-complete recovery with minimal residual deficits. Should continue to improve gradually over next 3-6 months. Can resume most normal activities. Main limitation is cannot drive yet (will reassess after driving evaluation). Otherwise functionally independent. Will follow annually unless new symptoms develop.

clinical_timeline.provider_note_snippet: 74F for routine health maintenance and chronic disease management. Patient doing very well 3.5 months post-stroke. INTERVAL HISTORY: No new symptoms, no chest pain, no palpitations, no neurologic symptoms, no falls, no bleeding episodes. Feeling 'back to normal' per patient. Completed outpatient speech therapy 2 weeks ago - discharged at maximum benefit. PHYSICAL EXAM: Well-appearing, alert, conversing fluently. BP 128/76, HR 78 irregularly irregular (AFib). Cardiovascular: Irregularly irregular rhythm, no murmurs. Neurologic: Speech fluent, strength 5/5 all extremities, gait normal. CHRONIC DISEASE MANAGEMENT: (1) ATRIAL FIBRILLATION: Rate controlled (HR 78), anticoagulated on apixaban. No symptoms. Adherence excellent per daughter's supervision. No bleeding complications. (2) HYPERTENSION: Well-controlled on amlodipine 5mg + metoprolol. BP 128/76 (goal <140/90 for age, achieved). (3) HYPOTHYROIDISM: TSH 2.2 (normal range), well-controlled on levothyroxine 75mcg. (4) HYPERLIPIDEMIA: On high-intensity statin post-stroke. LDL 58 (goal <70, achieved). HDL 52 (good). (5) CHRONIC KIDNEY DISEASE: Stage 3a, stable GFR 58. Monitoring for DOAC dosing. MEDICATION ADHERENCE: Daughter reports patient taking ALL medications as prescribed without missing doses. Using pill organizer, phone reminders, daily check-ins. Patient states 'medications are my lifeline now.' FALL RISK: Patient ambulating normally without assistive device. Home safety measures in place (grab bars, removed rugs). No falls since stroke. On anticoagulation, falls would be high-risk for intracranial bleeding - emphasized continued fall prevention. HEALTH MAINTENANCE: Age 74 female - due for several screening tests: (1) MAMMOGRAM: Last one 2 years ago (2022) - due for screening. Ordered. (2) COLONOSCOPY: Last one 2018 (6 years ago) - due for repeat (every 10 years if normal, but patient now 74, may consider if life expectancy >10 years). Patient interested in screening. Referred to GI. (3) BONE DENSITY: Never had DEXA scan. Age 74, female, Asian (lower peak bone mass), on no estrogen - should screen for osteoporosis. Ordered. (4) VACCINATIONS: Influenza vaccine due in September (will give at next visit). Pneumococcal vaccine up to date. COVID vaccine - patient had bivalent booster 1 year ago, will offer updated vaccine when available. (5) CANCER SCREENING: Up to date with Pap smears (stopped at age 65 after normal screens). FUNCTIONAL STATUS: Independent with all ADLs and IADLs. Cooking, cleaning, managing finances (with daughter's oversight). Walking 30 minutes daily. Attending church weekly. Resumed volunteer work at church (helping with Sunday school materials). DRIVING: Completed driving evaluation last week - PASSED. Occupational therapist cleared patient for driving. Patient resumed driving short distances (church, grocery store). Not driving long distances or highways yet (daughter still takes her for medical appointments). QUALITY OF LIFE: Patient reports excellent quality of life. 'I'm grateful every day that I survived the stroke and recovered so well. I know it could have been much worse. I don't take anything for granted. I'm living my life fully, seeing my grandchildren (daughter just had first baby 2 weeks ago!), enjoying my retirement. The medications are a small price to pay for being able to live independently.' PROGNOSIS: Excellent. Patient has multiple chronic conditions (AFib, HTN, HLD, CKD, hypothyroidism, history of stroke) but ALL are well-controlled on medications. Excellent adherence. Good functional status. Strong family support. Should live many more years with good quality of life as long as continues current management.

clinical_timeline.provider_note_snippet: 6-MONTH POST-STROKE CARDIOLOGY FOLLOW-UP. Patient doing exceptionally well. Fully recovered from stroke, independent, excellent quality of life. INTERVAL HISTORY: No cardiovascular symptoms - no chest pain, no palpitations (AFib asymptomatic), no dyspnea, no edema, no syncope/presyncope. No neurologic symptoms - no weakness, numbness, visual changes, speech changes. No bleeding episodes on apixaban. PHYSICAL EXAM: Well-appearing elderly Asian female. BP 125/74 (excellent), HR 76 irregularly irregular (AFib). JVP normal. Lungs clear. Cardiac: Irregularly irregular rhythm, normal S1/S2, no murmurs. Extremities: No edema. ECG: Atrial fibrillation, ventricular rate 76 bpm, No acute ST-T changes, QRS narrow, QTc 420ms (normal). ATRIAL FIBRILLATION MANAGEMENT: (1) RATE CONTROL: Excellent - resting HR 76 (goal <110), asymptomatic. Metoprolol 25mg BID adequate. Patient tolerating well, no side effects. (2) ANTICOAGULATION: Apixaban 5mg BID - patient taking religiously. Daughter confirms zero missed doses over past 6 months. NO bleeding complications: No bruising, no blood in urine/stool, no gum bleeding, no epistaxis, No falls. This is IDEAL outcome on anticoagulation. GFR improved slightly to 62 (was 58) - still safe for apixaban standard dosing. (3) RHYTHM CONTROL: Not pursuing. Patient is 74, asymptomatic in AFib, rate controlled. Rhythm control (cardioversion, antiarrhythmic drugs) not indicated. Patient cannot take amiodarone (prior toxicity). Will continue rate control + anticoagulation strategy. STROKE PREVENTION: Patient is 6 months post-stroke. With apixaban and excellent adherence, stroke risk reduced from ~5%/year to <1%/year. NO recurrent strokes or TIAs in past 6 months (excellent). BNP 165 (normal, indicates no heart failure from chronic AFib). Echocardiogram from 2/28 showed normal LV function, mild LA enlargement. Will repeat in 1 year to ensure no progression. MEDICATION REVIEW: All 5 daily medications appropriate: Amlodipine (BP control), Metoprolol (rate control), Atorvastatin (stroke prevention), Levothyroxine (hypothyroidism), Apixaban (stroke prevention). All tolerated well. Patient not experiencing polypharmacy burden - states 'these pills keep me alive and healthy.' PATIENT SATISFACTION WITH DOAC: Patient very satisfied with switch from warfarin to apixaban. 'Best decision we made. No more blood draws every week, no more worrying about what I eat, no more adjusting doses. I just take my pills twice a day and I'm protected. So much simpler.' Daughter agrees: 'Much easier to manage. We know exactly what she needs to take every day. The peace of mind is worth the extra cost.' COST: Daughter paying $75/month co-pay for apixaban (Medicare Part D). Family considers this worthwhile investment given stroke prevention and improved quality of life vs. warfarin. FALL PREVENTION: Still emphasized. On anticoagulation, fall with head trauma = high risk intracranial bleed. Patient using handrails on stairs, removed throw rugs, wears sturdy shoes, avoids icy conditions. No falls in 6 months. PROGNOSIS: Excellent. Patient has permanent atrial fibrillation but well-rate-controlled and anticoagulated. Stroke risk minimized with apixaban adherence. Should continue to do well indefinitely with current management. PLAN: Continue all medications. Annual cardiology follow-up. Contact sooner if symptoms develop (palpitations with rapid rate, chest pain, dyspnea, neurologic symptoms, bleeding). Patient and family very pleased with care and outcomes.

Cranial nerves: Intact, symmetric facial movements. Motor: 5/5 strength all extremities bilateral. Sensory: Intact. Coordination: Normal. Gait: Normal, no assistive device needed. COGNITIVE STATUS: Patient passed Montreal Cognitive Assessment (MoCA) with score 28/30 (normal, >26). No cognitive deficits from stroke. Memory, attention, executive function all intact. MRI BRAIN: Will obtain surveillance MRI next week to assess: (1) Infarct evolution (should see chronic infarct, well-demarcated), (2) New silent infarcts (sometimes see small new infarcts on imaging despite no clinical symptoms), (3) Cerebral small vessel disease burden, (4) Baseline for future comparison. PROGNOSIS: EXCELLENT. Patient has achieved complete functional recovery from stroke 6 months ago. With excellent anticoagulation adherence on apixaban, risk of recurrent stroke <1%/year (vs 5%/year without anticoagulation). Patient should do well long-term. TRANSITION TO ANNUAL SURVEILLANCE: Given complete recovery and stable course, will transition from q6-month to annual neurology follow-up. The only difference is I'm more careful about my health now. I take my medications every single day without fail. I see my doctors regularly. I know how lucky I am. clinical_timeline.provider_note_snippet: 52F elementary school teacher presents with 2.5cm firm, irregular, non-tender mass in right breast upper outer quadrant at 10 o'clock, 3cm from nipple. No skin retraction, no nipple discharge. No palpable axillary lymphadenopathy. SIGNIFICANT FAMILY HISTORY: Mother had breast cancer diagnosed at age 58 (ER/PR positive, died at 64), maternal aunt had ovarian cancer at 62, father had colon cancer at 71. Given family history and mass characteristics, highly suspicious for malignancy. Patient very anxious - understandable given mother's death from breast cancer. Husband present, supportive. Ordered STAT imaging. Will see back in 3 days to discuss results. Patient on sertraline for anxiety, may need dose increase. Former smoker (quit 10 years ago). Married with 2 adult children local.

clinical_timeline.provider_note_snippet: Imaging results: Mammogram shows 2.8cm irregular, spiculated mass with microcalcifications - BI-RADS 5 (highly suggestive of malignancy). Ultrasound confirms 2.8 x 2.1 x 2.3cm irregular hypoechoic mass with posterior shadowing. RIGHT AXILLA: One enlarged 1.8cm lymph node with loss of fatty hilum - suspicious for metastatic involvement. Patient anxious but composed, husband present. Discussed high suspicion for breast cancer with likely lymph node spread. Core biopsy scheduled Monday. Provided written materials. Emphasized importance of both attending surgical oncology appointment together. Patient declined increasing sertraline for now - wants to 'get through the diagnosis first.'

new_acute: Invasive ductal carcinoma, right breast, Grade 2, ER+/PR+/HER2-, Stage IIA (T2N1M0) (C50.911)

clinical_timeline.provider_note_snippet: PATHOLOGY CONFIRMED: Invasive ductal carcinoma, Grade 2. Immunohistochemistry: ER 90% positive, PR 75% positive, HER2 negative (IHC 1+), Ki-67 18%. FNA of axillary lymph node positive for metastatic carcinoma. STAGING: T2N1M0 - Stage IIA breast cancer. Treatment plan discussed: NEOADJUVANT CHEMOTHERAPY first (to shrink tumor and treat micrometastatic disease), followed by surgery (likely mastectomy given 3cm tumor and node-positive disease), then radiation and long-term endocrine therapy (tamoxifen or aromatase inhibitor). Rationale for neoadjuvant approach: tumor >2cm, node-positive, may allow breast conservation if excellent response, allows assessment of chemo sensitivity. Ordered staging scans to rule out distant metastases. Echo and PFTs for chemo clearance. GENETIC TESTING given strong family history - mother breast ca age 58, aunt ovarian ca, father colon ca. If BRCA positive, may influence surgical decision (bilateral mastectomy). Patient and husband asking excellent questions. Fertility preservation discussed - patient completed childbearing (children ages 26 and 24). Medical oncology referral for chemo protocol selection.

clinical_timeline.chief_complaint: Chemotherapy treatment planning

new_acute: Stage IIA (cT2N1M0) invasive ductal carcinoma, ER+/PR+/HER2- (C50.911)

clinical_timeline.provider_note_snippet: ALL STAGING NEGATIVE for distant metastases. Breast MRI: 3.2cm right breast mass, no additional lesions, no chest wall invasion, left breast normal. CT chest/abd/pelvis: No metastases, right axillary adenopathy as expected. Bone scan: negative. Echo: Normal LV function EF 62%, no valvular abnormalities - CLEARED FOR ANTHRACYCLINE. PFTs: Normal spirometry. GENETIC TESTING: BRCA1 and BRCA2 NEGATIVE. Variant of uncertain significance in CHEK2 gene - will discuss bilateral mastectomy vs lumpectomy after assessing chemo response. TREATMENT PLAN: Dose-dense AC-T protocol: (1) Adriamycin (doxorubicin) 60mg/m + Cytoxan (cyclophosphamide) 600mg/m every 2 weeks x 4 cycles, (2) followed by Taxol (paclitaxel) 80mg/m weekly x 12 weeks. Supportive meds: Dexamethasone pre-med, granisetron for nausea (AVOIDING ONDANSETRON due to documented QT prolongation allergy), Neulasta on-body injector day after chemo for neutropenia prevention. SIDE EFFECTS COUNSELED: Hair loss will occur (complete alopecia expected by cycle 2), nausea (though well-managed with meds), fatigue, infection risk (nadir days 10-14), possible neuropathy from Taxol. Patient doing better emotionally - connected with breast cancer support group through hospital. Short-term disability paperwork completed - will take medical leave from teaching. Patient asked about scalp cooling to prevent hair loss - discussed limited efficacy, offered doxycycline scalp prophylaxis. Port placement Monday, first chemo Thursday.

clinical_timeline.provider_note_snippet: C1D1 AC chemotherapy administered. Port placed 2024-02-12 without complications - site clean, dry, intact. PREMEDICATIONS: Dexamethasone 12mg IV, Granisetron 1mg IV (avoiding ondansetron per allergy), Famotidine 20mg IV, Diphenhydramine 25mg IV. CHEMOTHERAPY: Doxorubicin 60mg/m IV push (102mg total, BSA 1.7m), Cyclophosphamide 600mg/m IV over 30min (1020mg total). Tolerated well, no acute reactions. Neulasta Onpro device applied to abdomen - will auto-deliver pegfilgrastim 24 hours post-chemo. DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS: Take dexamethasone as prescribed x3 days (reduces delayed nausea). Use granisetron and prochlorperazine PRN nausea. NEUTROPENIC PRECAUTIONS: No gardening, avoid crowds, wash hands frequently, check temp if feeling unwell, NO FRESH FLOWERS OR PLANTS. Nadir (lowest blood counts) expected days 10-14. CALL IMMEDIATELY FOR: Fever 100.4F, severe nausea/vomiting despite meds, chest pain, severe shortness of breath, signs of infection. Patient nervous but tolerated first infusion well. Husband present throughout. Reinforced infection precautions.

clinical_timeline.chief_complaint: Fever 101.8F at home, Day 11 post-chemo

active_chronic: Stage IIA breast cancer on chemotherapy (C50.911)

clinical_timeline.provider_note_snippet: FEBRILE NEUTROPENIA - oncologic emergency. Patient presents Day 11 post-AC chemo with fever 101.8F, ANC 0.3 (critically low). Feeling fatigued, mild chills, body aches. Denies cough, SOB, chest pain, abdominal pain, diarrhea, urinary symptoms, new rash. Exam: Ill-appearing, flushed, but alert and oriented. Lungs clear, heart tachycardic but regular, abdomen soft/non-tender. Port site clean without erythema or drainage. No oral mucositis. No CVA tenderness. LABS: Severe neutropenia ANC 0.3 (normal >1.5), hemoglobin dropped to 11.2, platelets adequate at 156. Lactate normal 1.2 (not septic). NO CLEAR SOURCE IDENTIFIED. Blood cultures drawn from 2 peripheral sites (not through port). Urinalysis negative. CXR clear - no infiltrates. MANAGEMENT: ADMITTED to oncology floor for IV broad-spectrum antibiotics. Started cefepime 2g IV q8h immediately (covers pseudomonas and gram-negatives). Strict neutropenic precautions: private room, no fresh flowers/plants, cooked food only, masks for all visitors. NPO except ice chips until afebrile and stable. HOLD Cycle 2 chemotherapy (scheduled 2024-02-29) - will reassess count recovery. Educated patient and husband on seriousness of neutropenic fever - can become life-threatening rapidly if untreated.

clinical_timeline.chief_complaint: Hospital Day 3, febrile neutropenia improving

started: Cefpodoxime 200mg PO BID x5 days (completion of antibiotic course at home)

active_chronic: Stage IIA breast cancer on chemotherapy (C50.911)

clinical_timeline.provider_note_snippet: Excellent response to antibiotics. Afebrile x48 hours (last fever 2/27 at 6am). ANC recovered to 1.8 (>1.5 threshold). Feeling much better, appetite improving, ambulating well. Blood cultures: NO GROWTH at 72 hours (final) - presumed viral vs occult bacterial infection that cleared. DISCHARGE HOME today. Complete oral cefpodoxime x5 more days. Resume baseline medications. CHEMOTHERAPY ADJUSTMENT: Cycle 2 DELAYED by 1 week (from 2/29 to 3/7) to allow better count recovery. Close monitoring going forward - if recurrent febrile neutropenia, will need dose reduction per protocol (reduce to 75% dose). Patient relieved to go home, anxious about next chemo cycle. Reassured this is common complication, we'll monitor closely. RTC 3/6 for pre-chemo evaluation.

clinical_timeline.chief_complaint: Completed 4 cycles AC chemotherapy, evaluate for Taxol initiation

active_chronic: Stage IIA breast cancer, partial response to chemotherapy (C50.911)

clinical_timeline.provider_note_snippet: AC CHEMOTHERAPY COMPLETED: 4 cycles total (last dose 2024-04-04). COMPLICATIONS: Had SECOND episode of febrile neutropenia during Cycle 3 (Day 11, ANC 0.4, admitted 24 hours). Required dose reduction to 75% for Cycles 3 and 4 per protocol. Tolerated reduced-dose cycles well without further neutropenic episodes. CURRENT STATUS: Cachectic-appearing, wearing wig (complete alopecia as expected). PHYSICAL EXAM: Right breast tumor NOW PALPABLE AS 1.5cm firm area (was 3cm at baseline) - SIGNIFICANT REDUCTION IN SIZE. No palpable axillary lymph nodes (previously had 1.8cm node). NEUROPATHY ASSESSMENT: Mild tingling/numbness in fingertips bilaterally (Grade 1 peripheral neuropathy). Can still button clothes, write, type. No motor weakness. TUMOR RESPONSE: Ultrasound shows right breast mass now 1.6 x 1.2cm (decreased from 2.8 x 2.1cm) - 43% reduction in largest diameter. No abnormal axillary lymph nodes visualized. EXCELLENT PARTIAL RESPONSE to AC chemotherapy. PLAN: Proceed with weekly Paclitaxel 80mg/m x12 weeks (standard dose to start). Pre-meds: Dexamethasone 10mg IV, diphenhydramine 25mg IV, famotidine 20mg IV (standard hypersensitivity prophylaxis - taxanes have high reaction risk). Monitor neuropathy closely - may need dose adjustment if worsens. No Neulasta with weekly Taxol (lower myelosuppression than AC). Given excellent response, surgical planning to begin - meeting with surgeon in 3 weeks to discuss lumpectomy + radiation vs mastectomy. Lumpectomy may now be possible given dramatic tumor shrinkage. Patient tolerating treatment well emotionally, support system strong.

clinical_timeline.chief_complaint: Taxol Week 1 - HYPERSENSITIVITY REACTION

active_chronic: Stage IIA breast cancer on chemotherapy (C50.911)

procedures_ordered: Observation in infusion center x2 hours
Medical oncology urgent consultation for alternative regimen
clinical_timeline.provider_note_snippet: ACUTE HYPERSENSITIVITY REACTION TO PACLITAXEL - Code initiated. TIMELINE: Infusion started 15:00 with standard pre-medications (dexamethasone 10mg IV, diphenhydramine 25mg IV, famotidine 20mg IV). At 15:45 (45 minutes into planned 60-minute infusion, ~75% dose delivered), patient developed: ACUTE ONSET flushing, chest tightness, difficulty breathing, severe anxiety. VITALS AT ONSET: BP 156/92 (hypertensive), HR 112 (tachycardic), O2 sat 94% on room air (hypoxic), audible wheezing. IMMEDIATE MANAGEMENT: (1) INFUSION STOPPED immediately, (2) IV access maintained, (3) Diphenhydramine 50mg IV STAT, (4) Hydrocortisone 100mg IV STAT, (5) Albuterol nebulizer for bronchospasm, (6) O2 2L nasal cannula. RESPONSE: Within 20 minutes, symptoms began improving. Wheezing resolved after second albuterol treatment. BP normalized to 128/78, HR 88, O2 sat 98% on 2L. Patient calmer after reassurance. DIAGNOSIS: Grade 3 hypersensitivity reaction to paclitaxel (moderate-severe, requiring treatment discontinuation). PLAN: (1) PACLITAXEL DISCONTINUED - cannot rechallenge, (2) Observed x2 hours in infusion center - stable, (3) Methylprednisolone 125mg IV before discharge, (4) Prednisone taper: 40mg daily x3 days, then 20mg x2 days, (5) Diphenhydramine 25mg PO q6h PRN, (6) URGENT medical oncology consultation to discuss alternative taxane options. OPTIONS: (a) Docetaxel (different taxane, lower cross-reactivity), (b) Paclitaxel desensitization protocol (prolonged infusion with intensive monitoring), (c) Capecitabine (oral chemo, different mechanism). Patient shaken by experience but recovering well. Husband present. Extensive counseling on what happened and next steps.

clinical_timeline.chief_complaint: Alternative chemotherapy planning after paclitaxel hypersensitivity

active_chronic: Stage IIA breast cancer, partial response to neoadjuvant chemotherapy (C50.911)

clinical_timeline.provider_note_snippet: Reviewed paclitaxel hypersensitivity reaction - classic presentation. Discussed treatment options: OPTION 1: Docetaxel (Taxotere) - different taxane formulation, less hypersensitivity but more myelosuppression, fluid retention. OPTION 2: Nab-paclitaxel (Abraxane) - albumin-bound paclitaxel, NO SOLVENT (solvent causes most reactions), much lower hypersensitivity risk (~2% vs 10% for standard paclitaxel), NO PREMEDICATIONS NEEDED. OPTION 3: Capecitabine oral chemotherapy - completely different class, but less data in neoadjuvant setting. DECISION: Nab-paclitaxel (Abraxane) 100mg/m weekly x12 weeks. RATIONALE: (1) Same active drug (paclitaxel) so maintains efficacy, (2) Cremophor-free formulation eliminates primary allergen, (3) Minimal cross-reactivity, (4) No premedications needed (though we'll give famotidine as precaution), (5) Well-tolerated, (6) Can complete intended taxane-based regimen. RISKS: Still small chance of reaction (~2%), neuropathy risk similar to paclitaxel, myelosuppression. Will monitor closely during first infusion - have emergency meds ready, slower infusion rate initially. Patient and husband understand risks vs benefits, willing to proceed. PERIPHERAL NEUROPATHY UPDATE: Grade 1 fingertip numbness unchanged, not interfering with function. Will monitor - if worsens to Grade 2 (moderate interference with ADLs), will reduce nab-paclitaxel dose to 75mg/m. Patient anxious about another reaction but reassured by different formulation.

clinical_timeline.chief_complaint: Completed nab-paclitaxel, surgical planning

active_chronic: Stage IIA breast cancer, excellent response to neoadjuvant chemotherapy (C50.911)

clinical_timeline.provider_note_snippet: NAB-PACLITAXEL COMPLETED: 12 weekly doses total (last dose 2024-07-18). NO HYPERSENSITIVITY REACTIONS - tolerated much better than standard paclitaxel. Required dose reduction to 75mg/m at week 8 due to progressive neuropathy (Grade 12). FINAL TUMOR ASSESSMENT: Breast MRI shows right breast residual mass 0.9cm (started at 3.2cm) - 72% REDUCTION from baseline, 44% further reduction from post-AC assessment. OUTSTANDING RESPONSE to neoadjuvant chemotherapy overall. No abnormal lymph nodes visualized on MRI. PHYSICAL EXAM: Right breast - palpable 1cm firm area upper outer quadrant, significantly smaller. No palpable axillary nodes. PERIPHERAL NEUROPATHY: Now Grade 2 - numbness and tingling in fingers and toes bilaterally, some difficulty with fine motor tasks (buttoning small buttons, picking up coins). Can still perform most ADLs but with difficulty. Symptoms expected to slowly improve over 3-6 months after stopping chemo, though may have some permanent residual neuropathy. SURGICAL PLANNING: Given excellent response (>70% reduction), patient is NOW CANDIDATE FOR BREAST-CONSERVING SURGERY (lumpectomy). Initial tumor was 3.2cm making mastectomy likely, but dramatic response allows lumpectomy. Will discuss options: (1) Lumpectomy + sentinel lymph node biopsy + radiation, vs (2) Mastectomy (with or without reconstruction). CHEK2 VUS complicates decision - uncertain significance for contralateral breast cancer risk. Genetic counselor involved. Patient leaning toward lumpectomy - wants to preserve breast if oncologically safe. Surgery scheduled for mid-August after MRI surgical planning. Post-surgery: radiation therapy 6 weeks, then long-term endocrine therapy (likely aromatase inhibitor given post-menopausal) for 5-10 years. OVERALL: Excellent response to neoadjuvant chemotherapy despite complications (2 episodes febrile neutropenia requiring dose reduction, paclitaxel hypersensitivity requiring switch to nab-paclitaxel, progressive neuropathy). Demonstrates importance of completing treatment despite toxicities. Patient and family pleased with tumor response, hopeful about breast conservation.

clinical_timeline.chief_complaint: Post-lumpectomy pathology review, radiation planning

active_chronic: Breast cancer, status post neoadjuvant chemotherapy and lumpectomy, ypT1N0 (C50.911)

procedures_ordered: Bone density scan (baseline before aromatase inhibitor)
clinical_timeline.provider_note_snippet: SURGERY COMPLETED 2024-08-15: Right breast lumpectomy with sentinel lymph node biopsy. SURGICAL PATHOLOGY: PATHOLOGIC COMPLETE RESPONSE in lymph nodes - all 3 sentinel nodes NEGATIVE. Residual invasive carcinoma in breast 0.8cm (ypT1), Grade 2, ER+/PR+/HER2-, margins negative (>5mm all margins). FINAL STAGING: ypT1N0 - downstaged from initial cT2N1 (Stage IIA  Stage IA). OUTSTANDING RESPONSE to neoadjuvant chemotherapy. Surgical site healing well, no complications. NEUROPATHY UPDATE: Grade 2 peripheral neuropathy SLOWLY IMPROVING. Started gabapentin 300mg TID with some benefit. Still has numbness/tingling but fine motor function better. Physical therapy helping with hand exercises. May take 6-12 months for maximal recovery, likely some permanent residual symptoms. RADIATION THERAPY: Starting in 2 weeks. Plan: Whole breast radiation 50 Gy in 25 fractions over 5 weeks, with boost to tumor bed 10-16 Gy (5-8 fractions). ENDOCRINE THERAPY: Started anastrozole 1mg daily (aromatase inhibitor - patient post-menopausal, superior to tamoxifen). Will continue for 5-10 years. Baseline bone density ordered (aromatase inhibitors increase osteoporosis risk). SIDE EFFECTS COUNSELED: Joint pain/stiffness (arthralgias), hot flashes, bone density loss. Will monitor bone density annually, consider bisphosphonates if needed. PROGNOSIS: Excellent given pathologic downstaging and node-negative status. Estimated 5-year disease-free survival >90%, 10-year overall survival >85%. Patient and family relieved to have completed chemotherapy and surgery. Emotional about journey - from diagnosis to now 9 months later. Plans to return to teaching part-time in January after completing radiation. Hair regrowing (short pixie cut emerging). Support group has been invaluable. Discussed survivorship care plan: annual mammograms, clinical exams every 3-6 months for 3 years then annually, endocrine therapy adherence critical. GENETICS: BRCA negative, CHEK2 VUS - annual screening bilateral mammograms, no additional surgery recommended. Family history significant but genetic testing negative for high-penetrance mutations.

social_history_updates.employment: On medical leave from teaching, planning part-time return January 2025

achetype: Non-Small Cell Lung Cancer with Brain Metastases
chief_complaint: Persistent cough x3 months, now coughing up blood

ground_truth_correlations.description: Progressive respiratory symptoms with weight loss revealing advanced lung cancer with brain metastases
New neurological symptoms (headaches, confusion) correlating with brain metastases progression
EGFR mutation positive tumor allowing targeted therapy with dramatic initial response
Disease progression on targeted therapy with development of resistance requiring treatment change

clinical_timeline.chief_complaint: Persistent cough x3 months, worsening, now with some blood
clinical_timeline.provider_note_snippet: 64M retired construction worker presents with 3-month history of persistent dry cough, now productive with blood-streaked sputum x1 week. Initially attributed to 'bronchitis' treated with course of azithromycin without improvement. Reports progressive fatigue, decreased appetite. Denies fever, night sweats, chest pain. SMOKING HISTORY: 45 pack-years (1.5 packs/day x30 years), quit 5 years ago. Former heavy smoker - HIGH RISK. Wife concerned, pushed him to come in. Exam: Decreased breath sounds right upper lobe, no wheezing. Cough suppressant prescribed but NEED chest X-ray urgently given hemoptysis and smoking history. Patient reluctant about further workup, wants to 'see if cough improves.' Educated on importance of ruling out serious causes. Lives with wife, retired 2 years ago, enjoys woodworking.

social_history_updates.smoking: Former smoker, quit 5 years ago, 45 pack-year history
social_history_updates.living_situation: Lives with wife, 2 adult children out of state

clinical_timeline.chief_complaint: Chest X-ray results discussion

new_acute: Right upper lobe lung mass, suspicious for malignancy (R91.1)

clinical_timeline.provider_note_snippet: CHEST X-RAY RESULTS (2024-02-14): 4.5cm mass right upper lobe with irregular borders, concerning for malignancy. Possible right hilar lymphadenopathy. No pleural effusion. CRITICAL FINDING called to patient 2/14, asked to come in immediately. Patient and wife present, both visibly anxious. Discussed high suspicion for lung cancer given: (1) 45 pack-year smoking history, (2) hemoptysis, (3) large mass on X-ray, (4) weight loss (2 lbs since last week). Explained need for CT chest and bronchoscopy for tissue diagnosis. Patient tearful, stating 'I knew I should have quit sooner.' Wife supportive but also tearful. Referred urgently to pulmonology - appointment scheduled for 2/23. Ordered CT chest with contrast for 2/21. Discussed prognosis depends on staging but emphasized importance of quick workup. Patient asking about treatment options - explained need diagnosis first. Construction background - possible asbestos exposure adds to risk.

clinical_timeline.chief_complaint: Biopsy results, staging complete

new_acute: Adenocarcinoma of lung, right upper lobe, Stage IV (C34.11)

procedures_ordered: Molecular testing: EGFR, ALK, ROS1, PD-L1
clinical_timeline.provider_note_snippet: DEVASTATING NEWS. CT CHEST (2/21): 5.2cm mass right upper lobe with spiculated margins, extensive right hilar and mediastinal lymphadenopathy (largest node 3.8cm), possible small left pleural effusion. BRONCHOSCOPY (2/28): Biopsy confirmed ADENOCARCINOMA of lung. PET SCAN (3/5): Hypermetabolic RUL mass SUV 12.8, mediastinal nodes SUV 8.2-11.4, THREE hypermetabolic brain lesions (right frontal 1.8cm SUV 6.2, left parietal 1.2cm SUV 5.8, right cerebellar 0.9cm SUV 4.9), NO other distant metastases identified. BRAIN MRI pending to better characterize lesions. STAGING: cT3N3M1c - STAGE IV NON-SMALL CELL LUNG CANCER with BRAIN METASTASES. Patient and wife devastated. Patient now asking about 'how long do I have?' - explained survival varies greatly depending on molecular markers and treatment response. Emphasized importance of molecular testing - if EGFR or ALK mutation present, targeted therapy available with better outcomes. Started dexamethasone for brain metastases (reduce cerebral edema). Urgent oncology referral - appointment 3/12. Patient reports new symptoms since last visit: mild headaches (now makes sense - brain mets), increased fatigue, weight loss continues (now 6 lbs total). Denies confusion, seizures, focal weakness. Cough improving slightly with tumor treatment. MOLECULAR TESTING ordered on biopsy tissue - results in 7-10 days. Patient asking about clinical trials. Wife asking about brain surgery vs radiation. Explained neurosurgery/radiation oncology will discuss best approach for brain lesions. Family wants adult children (California and Texas) to fly in for oncology appointment. Patient expressing regret about not quitting smoking sooner, anger at himself. Discussed: (1) This is not his 'fault,' (2) Focus on treatment options now, (3) Support resources available including oncology social work, palliative care.

social_history_updates.support_system: Wife primary caregiver, adult children in California and Texas planning to visit

clinical_timeline.chief_complaint: Treatment planning, molecular results available

new_acute: Stage IV EGFR-mutant adenocarcinoma of lung with brain metastases (C34.11, C79.31)

procedures_ordered: Whole brain radiation therapy (WBRT) - 10 fractions starting 3/25
clinical_timeline.provider_note_snippet: EXCELLENT NEWS ON MOLECULAR TESTING: EGFR EXON 19 DELETION MUTATION DETECTED. This is TARGETABLE mutation found in ~15% of lung adenocarcinomas, more common in never/former light smokers and Asian patients. Also found: PD-L1 expression 60% (high). ALK/ROS1 negative. BRAIN MRI (3/15): Confirmed three metastatic lesions - right frontal 2.1cm with surrounding edema, left parietal 1.4cm, right cerebellar 1.0cm. Mild mass effect from frontal lesion but no midline shift. TREATMENT PLAN: (1) OSIMERTINIB (Tagrisso) 80mg PO daily - third-generation EGFR tyrosine kinase inhibitor, excellent CNS penetration (critical for brain mets), generally well-tolerated. Expected side effects: diarrhea, rash, dry skin, nail changes, QT prolongation (need baseline EKG). (2) WHOLE BRAIN RADIATION (WBRT) 30 Gy in 10 fractions starting Monday - for brain metastases control. Neurosurgery reviewed case, recommends WBRT over surgical resection given 3 lesions and good performance status. (3) Levetiracetam for seizure prophylaxis (brain mets put at risk). (4) Continue dexamethasone, taper slowly after radiation. PROGNOSIS DISCUSSION: Stage IV NSCLC with EGFR mutation - median survival 18-24 months with osimertinib, some patients 3-5+ years. Much better than EGFR-negative (median 6-12 months). Response rates to osimertinib ~80%, including brain metastases. Patient and family relieved to have 'good mutation' and oral medication option. Adult children both present (flew in from CA and TX). Extensive discussion about goals of care - treatment is PALLIATIVE (not curative) but can provide excellent quality of life and prolonged survival. Patient wants aggressive treatment. Discussed realistic expectations: likely will respond initially, but eventually cancer will progress/develop resistance. Palliative care consult for symptom management, advance care planning. Patient asking about continuing work (does woodworking, small furniture business from home) - encouraged as tolerated. Side effects monitoring: Weekly CBC first month, then monthly. EKG at 2 weeks and periodically (QT prolongation risk). Patient started on osimertinib today.

clinical_timeline.chief_complaint: Post-radiation follow-up, assess treatment response

active_chronic: Stage IV EGFR-mutant lung adenocarcinoma on targeted therapy (C34.11)

clinical_timeline.provider_note_snippet: DRAMATIC CLINICAL IMPROVEMENT. Patient reports feeling 'so much better' - cough almost completely resolved, energy improving, appetite returning, gaining weight (up 4 lbs). Completed WBRT 4/8 (10 fractions). Now 8 weeks on osimertinib. RADIATION SIDE EFFECTS: Moderate fatigue (expected, improving), mild alopecia (hair thinning, expected to regrow), some memory/concentration difficulties (discussed this is common after WBRT, may improve but could persist - 'chemo brain'). OSIMERTINIB SIDE EFFECTS: Mild diarrhea 2-3x/week (Grade 1, manageable with loperamide), dry skin/rash on trunk and arms (Grade 1, using aquaphor), some nail changes (ridging, brittleness). No QT prolongation on EKG. NEURO STATUS: No headaches, no confusion, no seizures. Dexamethasone tapered to 2mg daily, plan to discontinue in 2 weeks. IMAGING PENDING: Brain MRI scheduled today, chest CT scheduled tomorrow - will review results next visit. Physical exam: Alert, oriented, appears well. Lungs clear, improved from prior. No focal neurological deficits. Skin: Mild erythematous papular rash on chest/back, not bothersome. Family reports patient 'back to his old self' - working in woodshop again, more social. Patient and wife celebrating 40th anniversary next month, planning small family gathering. Adult son (California) staying for 2 weeks to help around house. Patient expressing gratitude for treatment response. Discussed: (1) Responses can be durable but cancer may eventually progress, (2) Continue osimertinib indefinitely until progression or intolerable toxicity, (3) Close monitoring with scans every 8-12 weeks initially.

clinical_timeline.chief_complaint: Imaging results discussion

new_acute: Stage IV EGFR-mutant lung adenocarcinoma, partial response to osimertinib (C34.11)

clinical_timeline.provider_note_snippet: EXCELLENT IMAGING RESULTS - PARTIAL RESPONSE. BRAIN MRI (5/17): All three brain metastases SIGNIFICANTLY DECREASED IN SIZE. Right frontal lesion 2.1cm  1.2cm (43% reduction), left parietal 1.4cm  0.7cm (50% reduction), right cerebellar 1.0cm  0.5cm (50% reduction). Markedly reduced surrounding edema. No new lesions. CT CHEST/ABD/PELVIS (5/18): Right upper lobe mass 5.2cm  3.1cm (40% reduction). Mediastinal lymph nodes markedly decreased, largest now 1.8cm (was 3.8cm, 53% reduction). Small pleural effusion resolved. No new metastases. Liver, adrenals, bones normal. RESPONSE ASSESSMENT: PARTIAL RESPONSE by RECIST criteria (>30% reduction in target lesions). This is EXCELLENT response to osimertinib at 8 weeks - typical of EGFR-mutant tumors. Patient and wife elated with results. Patient asking 'does this mean I'm cured?' - unfortunately had to explain this is NOT curative but is excellent disease control. Cancer will likely eventually develop resistance to osimertinib (median time to progression 18-24 months), but some patients maintain response for years. When progression occurs, second-line chemotherapy options available. PLAN: (1) Continue osimertinib 80mg daily, (2) Dexamethasone discontinued (brain mets responding well, no edema), (3) Repeat scans in 3 months, (4) Monthly labs, (5) Continue seizure prophylaxis, (6) Encouraged to maintain activities, quality of life. Patient back to baseline weight, working regularly in woodshop (building grandchild's crib currently). Anniversary celebration went well. Patient and family adjusting to 'new normal' of living with cancer.

clinical_timeline.chief_complaint: 3-month surveillance imaging and exam

new_acute: Stage IV EGFR-mutant lung adenocarcinoma, continued response to osimertinib (C34.11)

clinical_timeline.provider_note_snippet: 6-MONTH FOLLOW-UP. Patient continues to do remarkably well. Minimal symptoms - occasional dry cough, well-controlled diarrhea (1-2x/week), mild skin dryness. Energy excellent, appetite good, weight stable/increasing. Working full-time in woodshop, completed multiple furniture projects. IMAGING RESULTS (8/14 and 8/15): CONTINUED RESPONSE. BRAIN MRI: All lesions stable to slightly smaller. Right frontal 1.2cm  0.9cm, left parietal 0.7cm  0.5cm, right cerebellar 0.5cm  0.4cm. No new lesions. No edema. CT CHEST: RUL mass 3.1cm  2.6cm (16% further reduction, 50% total from baseline). Mediastinal nodes continued decrease, largest 1.2cm. No pleural effusion. CT ABDOMEN/PELVIS: No metastases. Incidental note: Liver appears normal. ASSESSMENT: CONTINUED PARTIAL RESPONSE after 6 months of osimertinib. This is excellent - maintaining response without significant toxicity. Physical exam: Well-appearing, no distress. ECOG performance status 0-1 (fully active). Lungs clear. No focal neuro deficits, cognition intact. Skin changes minimal. Patient and family thrilled.
