First grandchild born last month (son in California), patient able to travel to meet grandson. Patient saying 'I never thought I'd see this day' given initial Stage IV diagnosis. Discussed cautious optimism - he's doing great but must continue vigilance. PLAN: Continue current regimen, repeat imaging in 3 months. Patient asking about 'how long can this last?' - explained responses vary widely, some patients years, median ~2 years before resistance develops. When/if progression occurs, have second-line options (platinum-doublet chemotherapy, clinical trials). Encouraged to enjoy current quality of life.

social_history_updates.family_updates: First grandchild born, patient able to travel to California to visit

clinical_timeline.chief_complaint: Increased fatigue, mild cough returning, loss of appetite x2 weeks

new_acute: Stage IV EGFR-mutant lung adenocarcinoma, possible disease progression (C34.11)

clinical_timeline.provider_note_snippet: CONCERNING SYMPTOM CHANGES. Patient reports 2-week history of increasing fatigue, decreased appetite, dry cough returning (not productive, no hemoptysis). Wife notes he's sleeping more, less interested in woodshop. Weight down 5 lbs from August. No headaches, no confusion, no focal weakness. PHYSICAL EXAM: Appears fatigued but alert. Lungs: Decreased breath sounds right upper lobe again (had improved). Abdomen: Liver edge palpable 2cm below costal margin (was not palpable before), no tenderness. LABS CONCERNING: NEW LIVER ENZYME ELEVATION - ALT 88 (was 35), AST 102 (was 30), Alk phos 178 (was normal range), albumin dropping to 3.4. This pattern suggests possible hepatic metastases vs drug toxicity. Hemoglobin also dropping 11.8 (was 12.6). CLINICAL CONCERN: After 9 months of excellent response to osimertinib, now concerning symptoms + lab changes raising suspicion for DISEASE PROGRESSION. This timeline (9 months) is within expected range for development of resistance to EGFR TKIs. Alternatively, could be osimertinib hepatotoxicity (rare but occurs). Ordered STAT imaging - CT chest/abd/pelvis today. Patient and wife very worried - 'is the cancer back?' Explained need imaging to assess. If progression, will need to discuss second-line treatment options. If drug toxicity, may need to hold osimertinib temporarily or permanently. Contacted medical oncology for urgent appointment next week pending imaging results. Patient expressing fear, stating he 'knew it was too good to last.' Wife tearful. Reassured that if progression, have additional treatment options available.

clinical_timeline.chief_complaint: Imaging results - disease progression discussion

new_acute: Stage IV EGFR-mutant lung adenocarcinoma with acquired resistance, progressive disease (C34.11)

referrals: Palliative care - symptom management and goals of care discussion
clinical_timeline.provider_note_snippet: DISEASE PROGRESSION CONFIRMED - ACQUIRED RESISTANCE TO OSIMERTINIB. CT CHEST/ABD/PELVIS (11/23): (1) Right upper lobe mass INCREASED 2.6cm  4.8cm (85% increase from prior, though still smaller than baseline 5.2cm). (2) NEW LIVER METASTASES - at least 6 lesions ranging 0.8-2.4cm throughout both lobes, largest in segment 7. Explain elevated LFTs. (3) Mediastinal lymphadenopathy slightly increased. (4) Small right pleural effusion new. BRAIN MRI (11/24): Brain metastases STABLE - no new lesions, existing lesions unchanged from prior (good CNS control maintained). ASSESSMENT: PROGRESSIVE DISEASE after 9 months of osimertinib therapy. This represents ACQUIRED RESISTANCE to EGFR TKI - nearly universal occurrence, median time to progression 18-24 months (patient had 9 months, slightly shorter than median but within expected range). Mechanisms of resistance: T790M mutation (though patient already on 3rd-gen TKI), C797S mutation, MET amplification, BRAF mutation, small cell transformation, others. TREATMENT OPTIONS DISCUSSED: OPTION 1: Platinum-based chemotherapy doublet (Carboplatin + Pemetrexed) - standard second-line for EGFR-mutant NSCLC after TKI failure. Expected response rate 30-40%, median PFS 4-6 months. Side effects: myelosuppression, fatigue, nausea, neuropathy. OPTION 2: Clinical trial (discussed available trials, none perfect match currently). OPTION 3: Best supportive care only. PATIENT DECISION: Wants to proceed with chemotherapy - 'I want to fight, see my grandson grow up.' PLAN: (1) DISCONTINUE osimertinib (no longer effective, may contribute to liver toxicity), (2) Carboplatin AUC 5 + Pemetrexed 500mg/m IV every 3 weeks x 4-6 cycles, then pemetrexed maintenance if responding, (3) Port placement Wednesday, (4) First cycle Friday (C1D1), (5) Standard pre-meds and supportive care, (6) Restaging scans after cycle 2. PROGNOSIS DISCUSSION: Median survival after progression on EGFR TKI with chemotherapy 8-12 months. Patient understanding realistic expectations - this is for quality of life and time, not cure. Palliative care referral for symptom management, advance care planning. Patient and wife tearful but determined. Adult children planning to visit for holidays. Patient asking about immunotherapy - explained PD-L1 was 60% but immunotherapy generally less effective after EGFR TKI resistance, chemotherapy preferred. May consider later if progression.

clinical_timeline.chief_complaint: Post-Cycle 2 evaluation, assess tolerance and early response

started: Vitamin B12 1000mcg IM every 3 weeks (with pemetrexed)
Dexamethasone 4mg BID days before and after chemo

new_acute: Stage IV lung adenocarcinoma on second-line chemotherapy (C34.11)

procedures_ordered: Consider Neulasta if ANC drops further
clinical_timeline.provider_note_snippet: COMPLETED 2 CYCLES OF CARBOPLATIN/PEMETREXED (C1D1: 12/6, C2D1: 12/27). TOLERANCE: Moderate side effects as expected. CHEMOTHERAPY TOXICITIES: (1) Myelosuppression - hemoglobin dropped to 10.2 (Grade 1 anemia), platelets 145 (Grade 1 thrombocytopenia), ANC 2.4 (adequate but lower than baseline). May need Neulasta if drops further. (2) Fatigue - moderate (Grade 2), limiting some activities but still functional. Napping daily. (3) Nausea - well-controlled with prochlorperazine, minimal vomiting. (4) Appetite decreased, weight down 2 lbs. (5) No significant neuropathy (carboplatin less neurotoxic than cisplatin). LFTs IMPROVING: ALT 68 (was 92), AST 72 (was 108), Alk phos 156 (was 185) - suggests liver mets may be responding. CLINICAL STATUS: Patient reports cough slightly improved, energy 'not great but okay.' Not working in woodshop much - 'too tired.' Wife reports he's sleeping 10-12 hours/night. RESTAGING SCANS ordered for next week (after cycle 2, before cycle 3) - standard timing to assess response. If responding, will complete 4 cycles then transition to pemetrexed maintenance monotherapy (less myelosuppressive). If stable disease, continue current regimen. If progression, will need to discuss third-line options (clinical trial, immunotherapy trial, hospice focus). Patient and wife anxious about scan results. Holidays difficult - patient wanted to host Christmas but too fatigued, son (TX) bringing family to them instead. Grandson now 4 months old, patient able to hold/interact but tires quickly. Palliative care has been very helpful with symptom management and emotional support. Advance directive completed - patient wants 'everything reasonable' but no CPR if cardiac arrest, no prolonged ICU care, wants quality over quantity. Patient stating 'I just want to see my grandson's first birthday in July.' Wife asking about prognosis - median 8-12 months from progression, but individual variation. Imaging results will guide next steps. Patient tolerating chemotherapy reasonably well given circumstances.

social_history_updates.functional_status: Declining - fatigue limiting activities, not working in woodshop
social_history_updates.goals_of_care: Advance directive completed, wants reasonable treatments but focused on quality time with family

archetype: Progressive metastatic cancer with treatment resistance
chief_complaint: Elevated PSA on routine screening, no symptoms

ground_truth_correlations.description: Progressive PSA elevation despite androgen deprivation therapy indicating castration resistance
New bone pain correlating with widespread bone metastases on imaging
Progressive bone pain and skeletal-related events requiring palliative radiation and bone-targeted therapy
Rising PSA and new metastases on second-line therapy indicating disease progression

clinical_timeline.chief_complaint: Annual physical, PSA screening
procedures_ordered: Urology referral if PSA remains elevated
clinical_timeline.provider_note_snippet: 72M African American male for annual physical. Patient overall feeling well, no urinary symptoms, no bone pain, no weight loss. SIGNIFICANT RISK FACTORS: (1) African American race - 2x higher prostate cancer risk, (2) Age 72, (3) Family history - father had prostate cancer diagnosed age 68. Last PSA 2 years ago was 4.2 ng/mL. TODAY'S PSA: 8.4 ng/mL - SIGNIFICANT ELEVATION from 4.2 (doubled). DRE: Prostate mildly enlarged, firm nodule right lobe, no tenderness. CONCERN: PSA doubling time concerning for malignancy, especially with abnormal DRE and risk factors. No recent UTI, no recent ejaculation (asked - last sexual activity >1 week ago). Plan: Repeat PSA in 6 weeks to confirm elevation (can have false elevations from various causes). If remains >4.0, will refer to urology for prostate biopsy. Patient aware of prostate cancer risk given family history. Retired postal worker, lives with wife of 48 years, 3 adult children. Never smoker, occasional alcohol.

social_history_updates.family_history: Father had prostate cancer diagnosed age 68, died age 76 (cardiac arrest)
social_history_updates.living_situation: Lives with wife, 3 adult children in same city

clinical_timeline.chief_complaint: Prostate biopsy results discussion
clinical_timeline.provider_note_snippet: Patient returns with wife for prostate biopsy results from urology (performed 7/28). PATHOLOGY: Adenocarcinoma identified in 8 of 12 cores. GLEASON SCORE 4+5=9 (HIGH GRADE). Right lobe: 5 cores positive, up to 80% involvement. Left lobe: 3 cores positive, up to 60% involvement. NO perineural invasion noted but extensive tumor burden. STAGING: Clinical stage at least T2c (bilateral involvement). PSA confirmed elevated 8.8. DRE: Firm nodularity bilateral, no obvious extracapsular extension. RISK STRATIFICATION: HIGH-RISK prostate cancer based on: (1) Gleason 9 (very aggressive), (2) PSA >8, (3) Bilateral disease, (4) African American race. STAGING WORKUP ordered: Bone scan (screen for bone mets - common in high-risk disease), CT abdomen/pelvis (lymph nodes, visceral mets), CXR (lung mets rare but check). Referred to multidisciplinary team: urology oncology (surgical options), radiation oncology (EBRT + ADT vs brachytherapy options), medical oncology (systemic therapy). TREATMENT OPTIONS will depend on staging: If localized (M0): Radical prostatectomy vs radiation + ADT vs ADT alone (less aggressive approach). If metastatic (M1): ADT + abiraterone or enzalutamide (systemic therapy, not curative). Patient and wife shocked - 'I had no symptoms at all.' Explained high-grade prostate cancer often asymptomatic until advanced. Good that caught on screening. Patient asking about prognosis - explained depends on whether metastatic. If localized high-risk, 5-year survival 95%+. If metastatic, median survival 4-5 years with modern therapies. Patient wants 'aggressive treatment' - still active, wants to see grandchildren grow up (has 5 grandchildren ages 2-12).

clinical_timeline.chief_complaint: Staging results, treatment planning

started: Bicalutamide 50mg daily x28 days (antiandrogen flare protection)

new_acute: Metastatic prostate adenocarcinoma, Gleason 9, Stage IV (C61, C79.51)

procedures_ordered: Baseline bone density scan (ADT causes bone loss)
clinical_timeline.provider_note_snippet: STAGING COMPLETE - METASTATIC DISEASE. BONE SCAN (8/28): Multiple foci of increased uptake consistent with osseous metastases - bilateral ribs (4 lesions), thoracic spine (T7, T9, T11), lumbar spine (L3, L4), right iliac bone, left proximal femur. EXTENSIVE SKELETAL INVOLVEMENT. CT CHEST/ABD/PELVIS (8/30): Enlarged pelvic and retroperitoneal lymph nodes, largest 2.8cm left external iliac chain. Prostate gland enlarged, irregular. No visceral metastases (liver, lungs clear). STAGING: cT3aN1M1b - STAGE IV METASTATIC CASTRATION-SENSITIVE PROSTATE CANCER (mCSPC). TREATMENT PLAN: Androgen deprivation therapy (ADT) is BACKBONE of treatment. STARTED TODAY: (1) Leuprolide (Lupron Depot) 22.5mg IM every 3 months - LHRH agonist, suppresses testosterone production. First dose given today. (2) Bicalutamide 50mg PO daily x28 days - antiandrogen, prevents 'testosterone flare' from LHRH agonist (can temporarily worsen symptoms). Discontinue after 4 weeks. GOAL: Castrate testosterone level <50 ng/dL (ideally <20 ng/dL). Current testosterone 485 (normal range). Expect castrate levels by 4 weeks. ADDING ABIRATERONE at next visit (once castrate): Abiraterone 1000mg daily + prednisone 5mg BID - further androgen blockade. STAMPEDE trial showed ADT + abiraterone improves survival vs ADT alone in metastatic disease (median survival 5+ years vs 3.5 years). SIDE EFFECTS COUNSELED: (1) Hot flashes (very common, can use SSRI if severe), (2) Erectile dysfunction (expected, permanent), (3) Loss of libido, (4) Fatigue, (5) Muscle loss, weight gain, (6) Bone density loss (will monitor, consider bisphosphonates), (7) Cognitive changes ('chemo brain'), (8) Increased cardiovascular risk. Patient understanding this is PALLIATIVE treatment (not curative) but can provide years of disease control. PSA should drop dramatically - goal <0.2. Most patients respond initially (90-95%), median time to resistance 18-36 months with combination therapy. Patient stoic but concerned. Wife asking about quality of life - reassured most men tolerate ADT reasonably well. Discussed sexuality changes openly - patient and wife understanding. Grandchildren motivation for treatment. Bone density scan ordered (ADT accelerates osteoporosis). Will see in 6 weeks to check testosterone suppression and add abiraterone.

clinical_timeline.chief_complaint: 3-month ADT follow-up, assess response

continued: Leuprolide every 3 months (next dose due today)
started: Abiraterone 1000mg daily (4 tablets on empty stomach)
Calcium 1200mg daily with Vitamin D 2000 IU

clinical_timeline.provider_note_snippet: EXCELLENT RESPONSE TO ADT. PSA dropped from 9.2 to 0.8 (91% reduction) - this is excellent response. Testosterone successfully suppressed to 12 ng/dL (castrate range <20). Leuprolide injection #2 given today. NOW ADDING ABIRATERONE + PREDNISONE for enhanced androgen blockade. SIDE EFFECTS: (1) Hot flashes - SEVERE, 10-15/day, disrupting sleep. Started venlafaxine today (SSRI helps 50-60% reduction in hot flashes). (2) Erectile dysfunction - complete, as expected. Patient and wife adjusted expectations. (3) Fatigue - mild, manageable. (4) Weight gain - up 7 lbs (expected with ADT - decreased muscle mass, increased fat). HbA1c rising 6.4 (was 6.2) - ADT worsens insulin resistance. May need to increase metformin. (5) Mood changes - some irritability per wife, but no depression. PHYSICAL EXAM: Gynecomastia developing (mild breast tissue enlargement - common with ADT). Muscle tone decreased. Otherwise stable. BONE HEALTH: Started calcium/vitamin D supplementation. Will check bone density in 1 year - if osteoporosis, will add zoledronic acid (bisphosphonate). ABIRATERONE EDUCATION: Take on empty stomach (1 hour before or 2 hours after food). With prednisone (prevents mineralocorticoid excess from abiraterone). Monitor LFTs monthly first 3 months (abiraterone can cause hepatotoxicity). Monitor BP (prednisone + abiraterone can cause hypertension, fluid retention, hypokalemia). Patient tolerating treatment well overall. No bone pain currently. PSA goal <0.2 - expect further decline on abiraterone. Wife reports patient more emotional ('cries at commercials now') - explained this is hormone effect. Patient appreciating extra time with grandchildren, attending school events regularly.

clinical_timeline.chief_complaint: Rising PSA on treatment, new lower back pain

new_acute: Lower back pain, concerning for skeletal progression (M54.5)

clinical_timeline.provider_note_snippet: CONCERNING DEVELOPMENTS. PSA RISING: Nadir was 0.3 at 3 months ago (1/12), now 2.4 - this is BIOCHEMICAL PROGRESSION despite castrate testosterone (T=15). PSA risen on 3 consecutive tests: 0.3  0.8  2.4. This suggests development of CASTRATION-RESISTANT PROSTATE CANCER (CRPC) - tumor growing despite very low testosterone. Median time to resistance ~18 months, patient had 7 months (faster than expected). NEW SYMPTOM: Lower back pain x3 weeks, progressively worsening, 6/10 severity, worse with standing/walking, improves with rest. No radiation to legs, no weakness, no bowel/bladder changes. PHYSICAL EXAM: Tenderness to palpation lumbar spine L3-L4 region. No focal neurological deficits, straight leg raise negative. LABS: Alkaline phosphatase ELEVATED 142 (was 75 baseline) - suggests possible bone turnover from metastases. HbA1c rising 6.8 (steroid effect, ADT effect). BP elevated 152/92 - added HCTZ. ASSESSMENT: (1) BIOCHEMICAL PROGRESSION - likely CASTRATION-RESISTANT disease developing, (2) New back pain + rising alk phos concerning for SKELETAL PROGRESSION. Ordered restaging scans urgently. Started tramadol for pain. If imaging shows progression, will need to escalate therapy. OPTIONS: (1) Enzalutamide (different antiandrogen, may work after abiraterone resistance), (2) Docetaxel chemotherapy (platinum-standard for CRPC), (3) Radium-223 if symptomatic bone mets only (bone-targeting radiopharmaceutical), (4) Clinical trial. Patient concerned - 'I thought the treatment was working.' Explained this is expected eventual resistance but happened sooner than typical. Wife worried about pain progression. Reassured have multiple treatment options available. Patient still functional, able to care for grandchildren (though back pain limiting). Weight gain continues (now +11 lbs from start) - combination of ADT, prednisone, decreased activity.

clinical_timeline.chief_complaint: Imaging results - treatment plan for CRPC

new_acute: Metastatic castration-resistant prostate cancer with skeletal progression (C61, C79.51)

procedures_ordered: Palliative radiation to T11 - 8 Gy single fraction
Orthopedic spine consultation if neurological changes
referrals: Radiation oncology - urgent for T11 lesion
clinical_timeline.provider_note_snippet: IMAGING CONFIRMS PROGRESSIVE METASTATIC CRPC. BONE SCAN (5/2): SIGNIFICANT PROGRESSION - new lesions throughout skeleton. Previous lesions increased uptake intensity. NEW: cervical spine (C5, C6), multiple thoracic vertebrae (T4, T6, T8, T11-HIGH INTENSITY suggesting pathologic fracture risk or early fracture), lumbar spine (all levels), sacrum, bilateral femurs, bilateral humeri, skull. DIFFUSE SKELETAL INVOLVEMENT. CT CHEST/ABD/PELVIS (5/3): (1) T11 vertebral body compression fracture - likely pathologic given increased density and known metastases. Mild spinal canal narrowing but no cord compression. (2) Pelvic/retroperitoneal lymphadenopathy stable. (3) NO visceral metastases. (4) Prostate gland enlarged. PSA CONTINUES RISING: 4.8 (doubled since last month). Alkaline phosphatase 168 (bone turnover). Calcium mildly elevated 10.2 (mild hypercalcemia from bone mets). DIAGNOSIS: METASTATIC CASTRATION-RESISTANT PROSTATE CANCER (mCRPC) with symptomatic skeletal progression and pathologic fracture. TREATMENT PLAN: (1) SWITCH FROM ABIRATERONE TO ENZALUTAMIDE 160mg daily - second-generation antiandrogen, works through different mechanism, effective post-abiraterone. Expected PSA response 50-60%, median rPFS 8-10 months. Side effects: fatigue, diarrhea, hot flashes (already has), hypertension, RARE seizure risk (<1%). (2) ZOLEDRONIC ACID 4mg IV every 3 months - bisphosphonate, reduces skeletal-related events (fractures, spinal cord compression, need for radiation/surgery) by ~40%. Prevents bone loss from ADT. Side effects: flu-like symptoms first dose, rare osteonecrosis of jaw (dental exam before starting). First dose given today. (3) PALLIATIVE RADIATION to T11 - single 8 Gy fraction to prevent complete compression fracture and reduce pain. Scheduled for next week. (4) Continue ADT (leuprolide) - even in CRPC, maintain castrate testosterone. (5) PAIN MANAGEMENT: Continue tramadol, added oxycodone for breakthrough. May need long-acting opioid if pain worsens. PROGNOSIS DISCUSSION: Median survival with mCRPC ~2-3 years with sequential therapies. If enzalutamide fails, options include docetaxel chemotherapy, cabazitaxel, radium-223, lutetium-PSMA (if PSMA-positive), clinical trials. Patient understanding disease is progressing but treatable. Back pain 7/10 currently, limiting mobility. Wife concerned about fracture risk - discussed activity modifications, no heavy lifting, careful with falls. Patient wants to attend granddaughter's high school graduation in 2 weeks - reassured radiation should help pain by then.

clinical_timeline.chief_complaint: Post-radiation follow-up, pain assessment

dose_changed: Oxycodone IR 5mg q4h PRN breakthrough (was q6h)

procedures_ordered: Next zoledronic acid infusion in August
referrals: Pain management - consider interventional procedures if pain worsens
clinical_timeline.provider_note_snippet: PARTIAL RESPONSE TO ENZALUTAMIDE. PSA declined from 4.8 to 3.2 (33% reduction) - modest response, not as dramatic as initial ADT response but indicates some benefit. Testosterone remains castrate (16). Alkaline phosphatase improved 145 (was 168). Calcium normalized. RADIATION COMPLETED: T11 single fraction completed 5/17. Patient reports SIGNIFICANT PAIN IMPROVEMENT at T11 site - was 7/10, now 3/10, at rest, 5/10 with activity. Radiation very effective. Attended granddaughter's graduation pain controlled enough to sit through 2-hour ceremony. PAIN DISTRIBUTION: However, NEW PAIN developing - right hip 6/10, right shoulder 4/10, multiple rib sites 3-4/10. This is typical pattern with widespread bone mets - pain migrates as different lesions become symptomatic. Started long-acting oxycodone (extended-release) for baseline pain control, continue immediate-release for breakthrough. BOWEL REGIMEN: Aggressive bowel regimen for opioid-induced constipation - docusate (stool softener) + senna (stimulant laxative). Patient having BM every 2-3 days, manageable. ANEMIA: Hemoglobin declining 11.8 (was 12.4) - multifactorial: bone marrow infiltration by metastases, chronic disease, possible GI blood loss from NSAIDs (not using), zoledronic acid effect. Will monitor - may need erythropoietin or transfusion if drops further. FUNCTIONAL STATUS: Declining. Using cane for stability. No longer driving (safety concern with opioids + bone pain). Wife doing all driving, shopping. Patient still able to participate in family gatherings but tires easily. Granddaughter visits frequently, helps with yard work. SIDE EFFECTS: Enzalutamide causing moderate fatigue (worse than abiraterone), some dizziness with position changes. Hot flashes continue despite venlafaxine. Weight stable. Appetite fair. PLAN: Continue current regimen. If PSA continues to rise or pain becomes uncontrolled, will need to consider: (1) Docetaxel chemotherapy (most data, improves survival), (2) Radium-223 (bone-targeting, good for bone pain but doesn't help visceral disease if develops), (3) Cabazitaxel (second-line chemo), (4) Clinical trial. Patient and wife discussing advance care planning - wants quality of life prioritized. No interest in aggressive ICU care. Wants to remain at home as long as possible. Palliative care team involved, very helpful with symptom management and family support. Patient expressing gratitude for time with family, 'every day is a gift.'

social_history_updates.functional_status: Declining - using cane, no longer driving, fatigues easily
social_history_updates.goals_of_care: Quality of life prioritized, wants to remain at home, no aggressive ICU care

clinical_timeline.chief_complaint: PSA rising again, new abdominal discomfort

new_acute: Elevated LFTs concerning for hepatic metastases (R74.0)

procedures_ordered: Consider liver MRI if CT equivocal
clinical_timeline.provider_note_snippet: DISEASE PROGRESSION ON ENZALUTAMIDE. PSA RISING RAPIDLY: Was 3.2 in July, now 12.4 (nearly 4-fold increase in 2 months). This indicates ENZALUTAMIDE RESISTANCE developing - worked for only 4 months (shorter than expected median 8-10 months). NEW SYMPTOMS: (1) Right upper quadrant abdominal discomfort x3 weeks, dull ache, 4/10 severity, (2) Decreased appetite, (3) Increasing fatigue, (4) Weight loss - down 6 lbs since July. PHYSICAL EXAM: Liver edge palpable 4cm below costal margin (enlarged), firm, non-tender. No jaundice, no ascites. Continued bone tenderness multiple sites. LABS CONCERNING: (1) ALT 78, AST 92 - NEW ELEVATION (were normal). LDH 385 (elevated, nonspecific tumor marker). (2) Alkaline phosphatase 198 (rising - bone + possible liver source). (3) Albumin 3.2 (declining - nutritional status, liver synthesis). (4) Hemoglobin 10.8 (progressive anemia). ASSESSMENT: Highly suspicious for VISCERAL METASTASES (liver involvement) given: RUQ pain, hepatomegaly, elevated LFTs, rising PSA/alk phos/LDH. This would represent disease progression from bone-only to bone + visceral disease. Ordered urgent CT to confirm. IMPLICATIONS: If liver metastases confirmed, this changes prognosis significantly - median survival with visceral mets ~1 year vs 2-3 years with bone-only disease. TREATMENT OPTIONS: (1) DOCETAXEL CHEMOTHERAPY - platinum-standard for mCRPC, improves survival ~2-3 months, palliates symptoms. Given IV every 3 weeks, typical 6-10 cycles. Side effects: myelosuppression, neuropathy, fatigue, alopecia, fluid retention, nail changes. (2) CABAZITAXEL - second-line taxane chemo, if docetaxel fails. (3) Radium-223 - NOT appropriate if visceral mets (only works for bone). (4) Lutetium-PSMA - if PSMA-PET positive (radioligand therapy, newer option). (5) Clinical trial. (6) Best supportive care/hospice. Patient and wife somber - 'running out of options?' Explained still have chemotherapy which can help. Patient asking about quality vs quantity - wants treatment but not if it will make him 'too sick to enjoy family.' Discussed docetaxel generally tolerable, most men can maintain reasonable quality of life. Will discuss further after imaging confirms progression. Family meeting planned with all 3 children to discuss goals of care.

clinical_timeline.chief_complaint: Imaging results, chemotherapy decision

started: Ondansetron 16mg pre-chemo and q8h x2 days post-chemo

new_acute: Metastatic castration-resistant prostate cancer with hepatic and skeletal metastases, progressive (C61, C78.7, C79.51)

procedures_ordered: CBC and CMP before each cycle
referrals: Hospice consultation for advance planning (not enrolling yet)
Social work for financial assistance with medications
clinical_timeline.provider_note_snippet: IMAGING CONFIRMS EXTENSIVE PROGRESSION. CT CHEST/ABD/PELVIS (9/20): (1) LIVER METASTASES - at least 12 lesions throughout both lobes, largest 3.8cm in right lobe segment 7. NEW since last imaging. (2) Skeletal metastases - progression, increased size and number. (3) Lymphadenopathy increased, largest node 4.2cm retroperitoneum. (4) NEW small pulmonary nodules x3 in lungs, largest 8mm (likely metastases). (5) NO brain metastases (head CT done given rapid progression). BONE SCAN: Superscan appearance - diffuse increased uptake throughout skeleton, so extensive the kidneys barely visible. Consistent with massive skeletal tumor burden. PSA: 18.6 (continues rapid rise despite castrate testosterone). STAGING: Progression from M1b (bone-only) to M1c (bone + visceral metastases). PROGNOSIS: Median survival with M1c disease on chemotherapy ~12-18 months from this point. FAMILY MEETING: All 3 children present with patient and wife. Extensive discussion about goals of care. Patient's goals: (1) Control pain, (2) Maintain mental clarity as long as possible, (3) Stay at home with family, (4) See Christmas with family (3 months away), (5) If possible, see youngest grandson's 3rd birthday (5 months away). Patient DECLINING aggressive chemotherapy if side effects too severe but willing to TRY docetaxel. TREATMENT PLAN: DOCETAXEL 75mg/m IV every 3 weeks x up to 10 cycles (standard regimen). Pre-medications: dexamethasone 8mg x3 days (day before, day of, day after chemo - prevents hypersensitivity reactions and fluid retention), ondansetron for nausea. Filgrastim if neutropenia. EXPECTED OUTCOMES: PSA response 50%, symptom palliation (pain, fatigue) in responders, median survival benefit 2-3 months vs no chemo. SIDE EFFECTS: (1) Myelosuppression - neutropenia (infection risk), anemia (may need transfusions), thrombocytopenia (bleeding risk), (2) Peripheral neuropathy (numbness/tingling fingers/toes, may be permanent), (3) Fatigue (significant), (4) Alopecia (hair loss, expected), (5) Fluid retention (edema, weight gain despite cancer cachexia), (6) Nail changes (onycholysis, darkening), (7) Mucositis, diarrhea. Patient understanding this is PALLIATIVE - goal is symptom control and modest survival extension, not cure. Will proceed with chemo. Port placement next week, first cycle following week. Pain increasing - increased oxycodone ER. Appetite poor - discussed nutritional supplements (Ensure, Boost). Weight loss concerning - down 3 lbs since last visit (9 lbs total since July). Hospice consultation scheduled - NOT enrolling in hospice yet, but want relationship established for smooth transition when time comes. Social work helping with medication costs (financial strain with multiple expensive medications).

social_history_updates.goals_of_care: Control pain, maintain mental clarity, stay at home, see Christmas and grandson's 3rd birthday

clinical_timeline.chief_complaint: Post-Cycle 3 docetaxel, assess response and tolerance

started: Epoetin alfa (Procrit) 40,000 units SC weekly for anemia

active_chronic: Metastatic castration-resistant prostate cancer on chemotherapy (C61)

clinical_timeline.provider_note_snippet: COMPLETING CYCLE 3 DOCETAXEL (C1D1: 10/18, C2D1: 11/8, C3D1: 11/29, C4D1: 12/27 planned). MODEST PSA RESPONSE: PSA declined from 18.6 to 8.2 (56% reduction) - this is good partial response. Indicates chemotherapy having some effect on tumor. TOLERANCE: Moderate-severe side effects, manageable but challenging. CHEMOTHERAPY TOXICITIES: (1) MYELOSUPPRESSION - Hemoglobin 9.4 (moderate anemia, started epoetin alfa to stimulate RBC production). Platelets 128 (Grade 1 thrombocytopenia). ANC 2.1 (adequate, no infections). (2) PERIPHERAL NEUROPATHY - Grade 2, numbness/tingling bilateral hands and feet, 'glove-stocking distribution.' Some difficulty with fine motor (buttoning shirts, writing). Started gabapentin. May need docetaxel dose reduction if worsens to Grade 3. (3) FATIGUE - Severe (Grade 3), limiting ADLs. Sleeping 12-14 hours/day. Can participate in brief family gatherings but exhausted. (4) ALOPECIA - Complete hair loss (expected, not bothering patient - wearing baseball caps). (5) EDEMA - Mild lower extremity edema despite dexamethasone (docetaxel causes fluid retention). (6) WEIGHT LOSS - Down 5 lbs since starting chemo (total 13 lbs since July) - CANCER CACHEXIA. Appetite poor despite no significant nausea. Using nutritional supplements. (7) NAIL CHANGES - Darkening, some onycholysis (nail lifting from bed). (8) No significant mucositis or diarrhea. PAIN CONTROL: Adequate with increased opioid doses. Bone pain stable, not worsening. FUNCTIONAL STATUS: Significantly declined. Bed-to-chair most of day. Needs assistance with bathing, dressing. Wife primary caregiver with help from children. No longer able to go to grandchildren's events - they come to him. QUALITY OF LIFE: Patient and wife discussing whether to continue chemotherapy. Patient made it to CHRISTMAS GOAL - family gathering planned for Christmas Day at his home, all children and grandchildren coming. Patient stating 'I don't know if I want more chemo after this cycle - it's taking a lot out of me.' PLAN: Complete Cycle 4, then restaging CT. Will discuss results and reassess goals: (1) If significant response and patient willing, could continue docetaxel (usually do 6-10 cycles), (2) If minimal/no response or patient declining further chemo, transition to hospice focus. (3) Patient may continue ADT (leuprolide) even if stopping chemo - minimal side effects, may provide some disease control. Hospice reconsulted - patient/family not ready yet but understand may transition soon. Home health involved - nurse visits 3x/week, aide daily for personal care. Palliative care managing pain/symptoms excellently. Patient expressing peace with disease trajectory, gratitude for time with family. Wife emotional but coping well with strong family support.

social_history_updates.functional_status: Significantly declined - bed-to-chair, needs assistance with ADLs
social_history_updates.support: Wife primary caregiver with children helping, home health 3x/week, aide daily

allergies.reaction: Rash, unknown details (patient report from childhood)

ground_truth_correlations.description: Progressive BP elevation from 112/68 at baseline to 168/108, indicating preeclampsia development
Rising proteinuria (negative to 4+ protein) correlating with BP elevation and symptoms
Declining platelet count and elevated liver enzymes indicating HELLP syndrome development
Warning symptoms (severe headache, RUQ pain, visual changes) preceding severe preeclampsia with features

clinical_timeline.chief_complaint: First prenatal visit, about 10 weeks pregnant
procedures_ordered: Dating ultrasound - single viable IUP, 10w3d, EDD November 22, 2024
clinical_timeline.provider_note_snippet: First prenatal visit. G1P0 (primigravida). 28 yo African American female. Risk factors for preeclampsia: African American race, primigravida, family history (mother had preeclampsia). Pre-pregnancy weight 142 lbs, current 145 lbs. BMI 24.1 - normal. Baseline BP 112/68. No proteinuria. Patient healthy, no chronic conditions. Discussed warning signs of preeclampsia given risk factors. Standard prenatal care plan.

clinical_timeline.chief_complaint: Routine visit, 20 weeks, anatomy scan completed
procedures_ordered: Anatomy ultrasound - normal male fetus, all structures normal
clinical_timeline.provider_note_snippet: 20 week visit. Weight 155 lbs (10 lb gain, appropriate). BP 118/74 (stable). Anatomy scan normal. Fundal height appropriate. Fetal movement felt. No complaints. Hemoglobin 11.8 - borderline, monitoring. Continue routine prenatal care.

clinical_timeline.chief_complaint: 28 week visit, noticed some swelling in hands and feet past week
clinical_timeline.provider_note_snippet: 28 weeks. Weight 168 lbs (23 lb gain, upper limit of normal). BP 138/86 - ELEVATED from baseline 112/68. 1+ pitting edema bilateral hands and feet. Patient reports rings tight. Trace proteinuria on dipstick. Concerning for early preeclampsia. Ordered 24-hour urine protein. Uric acid 5.2 (borderline). Labs otherwise normal including platelets 228, liver enzymes normal. Patient to monitor BP at home twice daily. Return in 1 week for recheck. Instructed on warning signs: severe headache, vision changes, RUQ pain, decreased fetal movement. If 24-hr protein >300mg, diagnosis of preeclampsia confirmed.

clinical_timeline.chief_complaint: Follow-up visit, 31 weeks, having headaches past few days
clinical_timeline.provider_note_snippet: PREECLAMPSIA DIAGNOSED. 24-hr urine protein 450mg (>300 confirms diagnosis). BP 152/96. 2+ proteinuria. 2+ edema now to knees. Patient reports frontal headaches daily x3 days, responding to Tylenol. No visual changes, no RUQ pain. Platelets declining to 185 (from 228 three weeks ago). Liver enzymes mildly elevated: ALT 42, AST 48. Uric acid 6.8. This is preeclampsia without severe features currently, but trending worse. NST reactive. Fetus appropriate size. Plan: twice weekly NSTs and labs starting now. Steroids for fetal lung maturity given. Goal to reach 37 weeks if stable, but deliver earlier if severe features develop. Patient on modified bed rest. Home BP monitoring.

clinical_timeline.chief_complaint: Severe headache that won't go away, seeing spots, pain under right ribs

started: Magnesium sulfate IV for seizure prophylaxis
Betamethasone IM for fetal lung maturity (completed)

clinical_timeline.provider_note_snippet: SEVERE PREECLAMPSIA WITH HELLP SYNDROME - OBSTETRIC EMERGENCY. Patient presenting at 32w1d with severe unrelenting headache, visual disturbances (scotomas), and severe RUQ/epigastric pain. BP 168/108. HELLP SYNDROME CRITERIA MET: Hemolysis (Hgb 9.8 down from 10.8, LDH 685, schistocytes on smear), Elevated Liver enzymes (AST 242, ALT 168), Low Platelets (98, down from 185). 4+ proteinuria. Creatinine rising to 1.2. This represents severe preeclampsia with severe features. Started magnesium sulfate for seizure prophylaxis. Labetalol IV for BP control. Steroids completed. IMMEDIATE DELIVERY INDICATED despite 32 weeks gestation - maternal life-threatening condition. Cesarean section performed - delivered 32w1d male infant, 3 lbs 14 oz, Apgars 7/8, admitted to NICU. Patient to ICU for monitoring. This case demonstrates rapid progression from preeclampsia to HELLP syndrome over 1 week.

clinical_timeline.chief_complaint: Postpartum visit, 6 weeks after emergency delivery
clinical_timeline.provider_note_snippet: 6 week postpartum visit. Patient recovered well from severe preeclampsia/HELLP. Spent 4 days in ICU post-delivery, platelets and liver enzymes normalized by post-op day 3. Discharged on post-op day 5. BP normalized immediately after delivery. Current BP 132/82 - borderline but acceptable. No proteinuria. Labs normalized - platelets 242, liver enzymes normal, hemoglobin recovered. Weight 152 lbs (7 lbs above pre-pregnancy). Incision healed well. Baby in NICU for 3 weeks, now home and doing well. IMPORTANT COUNSELING: Patient at HIGH RISK for preeclampsia in future pregnancies (25-50% recurrence risk). Also at increased risk for chronic hypertension and cardiovascular disease later in life. Discussed low-dose aspirin for future pregnancies starting at 12 weeks. Recommended close preconception counseling before next pregnancy. Patient choosing long-acting reversible contraception (IUD) given risks.

expected_llm_challenges: Recognizing the progression from normal BP to preeclampsia to severe preeclampsia with HELLP
Understanding the significance of rising BP in conjunction with proteinuria
Identifying warning symptoms (headache, visual changes, RUQ pain) as severe features
Recognizing HELLP syndrome criteria (hemolysis, elevated liver enzymes, low platelets)
Understanding the rapidity of progression requiring emergency delivery despite prematurity
Appreciating long-term cardiovascular risk after preeclampsia/HELLP
evaluation_notes: This case tests ability to: (1) track progressive BP elevation across pregnancy, (2) recognize preeclampsia development through BP + proteinuria, (3) identify laboratory trends indicating worsening disease (declining platelets, rising liver enzymes), (4) connect warning symptoms with severe features requiring immediate intervention, (5) understand HELLP syndrome as life-threatening complication, (6) recognize the need for emergency delivery despite prematurity, and (7) appreciate long-term health implications. The LLM should flag concern at V3 with elevated BP and edema, recognize preeclampsia diagnosis at V4, identify rapid progression and severe features at V5 requiring emergency intervention, and understand at V6 the implications for future pregnancy and cardiovascular health. This case demonstrates how quickly preeclampsia can progress from mild to life-threatening.

archetype: Young adult cancer with early relapse requiring salvage therapy
chief_complaint: Persistent enlarged lymph nodes in neck x6 weeks, night sweats

ground_truth_correlations.description: Classic B symptoms (fever, night sweats, weight loss) with lymphadenopathy indicating lymphoma
Complete metabolic response to chemotherapy with normalization of PET scan
Early relapse within 12 months indicating high-risk disease requiring salvage therapy
Preparation for and successful autologous stem cell transplant for relapsed Hodgkin lymphoma

clinical_timeline.chief_complaint: Enlarged lymph nodes in neck x6 weeks, night sweats
clinical_timeline.provider_note_snippet: 28F graduate student presents with 6-week history of progressively enlarging lymph nodes in neck. Initially thought she had 'swollen glands from a cold' but nodes have grown larger. ASSOCIATED SYMPTOMS: (1) Drenching night sweats x4 weeks - soaking through sheets 3-4x/week, (2) Low-grade fevers, (3) 8 lb unintentional weight loss (was 140 lbs, now 132 lbs), (4) Generalized fatigue, (5) Occasional itching (pruritus). DENIES: cough, sore throat (initially had mild sore throat that resolved), chest pain, shortness of breath. NO sick contacts, no recent travel, no TB exposure. PHYSICAL EXAM: Multiple enlarged, firm, non-tender lymph nodes - bilateral cervical chains (largest 3cm right level II), bilateral supraclavicular nodes (1.5-2cm). No axillary or inguinal adenopathy palpated. Liver/spleen not palpably enlarged. No rashes. LABS: Mild anemia 11.8, elevated WBC 12.4, elevated ESR 68, elevated LDH 345 (nonspecific tumor marker). ASSESSMENT: CONSTELLATION OF B SYMPTOMS (fever, night sweats, weight loss) + LYMPHADENOPATHY is HIGHLY CONCERNING FOR LYMPHOMA, particularly Hodgkin lymphoma given patient's age (peak incidence 20-30s) and cervical/supraclavicular involvement. Differential includes infectious causes (EBV, HIV, TB) but clinical picture most concerning for malignancy. Ordered CT neck and chest X-ray. If imaging shows significant adenopathy, will need excisional lymph node biopsy (not FNA - need tissue architecture for lymphoma diagnosis). Patient is graduate student in psychology program, lives with roommate, no significant past medical history. No family history of cancer. Non-smoker, rare alcohol. Patient anxious about diagnosis - 'my friend's mother had lymphoma.' Reassured that if lymphoma, Hodgkin lymphoma in young adults highly curable (>80%).

social_history_updates.occupation: Graduate student - psychology PhD program, 2nd year
social_history_updates.support_system: Parents live 2 hours away, older sister nearby, close friend group

clinical_timeline.chief_complaint: CT results discussion, plan for biopsy

new_acute: Extensive lymphadenopathy, highly suspicious for lymphoma (R59.9)

procedures_ordered: PET-CT whole body (after biopsy confirms diagnosis)
clinical_timeline.provider_note_snippet: CT NECK/CHEST RESULTS (8/18): EXTENSIVE LYMPHADENOPATHY throughout cervical, supraclavicular, mediastinal regions. Cervical: Multiple enlarged nodes bilaterally, largest 3.5cm right level II. Supraclavicular: Bilateral adenopathy. MEDIASTINUM: BULKY MEDIASTINAL MASS measuring 8.5 x 7.2 x 10.4cm, occupying anterior mediastinum. No airway or vascular compression. Bilateral hilar adenopathy. No pleural effusion. ABDOMEN (incidental coverage): Enlarged paraaortic lymph nodes. IMPRESSION: Findings highly suggestive of lymphoma. Chest X-ray (8/14): Widened mediastinum (explains bulky mediastinal mass on CT). MONOSPOT AND HIV: Negative. ASSESSMENT: Imaging findings essentially diagnostic of lymphoma. Most likely HODGKIN LYMPHOMA given: (1) Young age, (2) Bulky mediastinal involvement (classic for Hodgkin), (3) Contiguous nodal spread pattern, (4) B symptoms present. Could also be mediastinal large B-cell lymphoma (subtype of non-Hodgkin). PLAN: Excisional lymph node biopsy scheduled with surgery for Wednesday (8/30) - will remove entire right cervical node for pathology. Need tissue architecture, immunohistochemistry, flow cytometry for definitive diagnosis. After diagnosis confirmed, will stage with PET-CT. Patient very anxious, brought parents to appointment. Extensive discussion about likely lymphoma diagnosis and high cure rates. Explained treatment will likely be combination chemotherapy (ABVD or similar regimen) x6 months. Discussed fertility preservation - chemotherapy can affect fertility. Patient not currently in relationship, would like to preserve fertility - referred to reproductive endocrinology for urgent consultation about egg freezing before starting chemo. Patient taking semester off from graduate program - school supportive, holding her spot. Parents staying with her for biopsy and initial treatment planning.

social_history_updates.education: Taking semester off from PhD program
social_history_updates.family_support: Parents staying with her, very supportive

clinical_timeline.chief_complaint: Biopsy results, staging, treatment planning

new_acute: Classical Hodgkin Lymphoma, Nodular Sclerosis subtype, Stage IIB with bulky mediastinal disease (C81.10)

procedures_ordered: First chemotherapy ABVD Cycle 1 Day 1 scheduled 9/22
Baseline pulmonary function tests (bleomycin toxicity monitoring)
clinical_timeline.provider_note_snippet: PATHOLOGY RESULTS (9/5): Classical Hodgkin Lymphoma, Nodular Sclerosis subtype. Lymph node architecture effaced by nodular infiltrate with broad bands of fibrosis. REED-STERNBERG CELLS identified (diagnostic of Hodgkin lymphoma). Immunohistochemistry: CD30+, CD15+, CD20-, CD45-, PAX5 weak+. Consistent with classical Hodgkin lymphoma, nodular sclerosis (most common subtype, 60-70% of Hodgkin cases). PET-CT STAGING (9/12): FDG-avid extensive lymphadenopathy - cervical (bilateral, SUV max 8.2), supraclavicular (bilateral, SUV 7.4), mediastinal mass (SUV 12.8), bilateral hilar nodes (SUV 6.8-9.2), paraaortic nodes (SUV 5.4). Spleen appears normal size, no focal splenic lesions. Liver normal. Bone marrow shows normal FDG uptake (no marrow involvement). STAGING: Stage IIB (B = B symptoms present: fever, night sweats, weight loss >10%). Stage II = involvement of 2+ lymph node regions on same side of diaphragm. Has cervical, supraclavicular, mediastinal, hilar involvement - all above diaphragm. BULKY DISEASE: Mediastinal mass 10.4cm, ratio of mass to thoracic diameter >0.33 (bulky disease definition). This makes her UNFAVORABLE Stage II (bulky disease is poor prognostic factor). TREATMENT PLAN: ABVD CHEMOTHERAPY (Adriamycin/doxorubicin, Bleomycin, Vinblastine, Dacarbazine) every 2 weeks x 6 cycles (12 weeks total), followed by RADIATION THERAPY to bulky mediastinal mass. ABVD is standard first-line for advanced/unfavorable Hodgkin. EXPECTED OUTCOMES: 80-85% cure rate for Stage IIB bulky disease with combined modality therapy (chemo + radiation). SIDE EFFECTS COUNSELED: (1) Nausea/vomiting (well-managed with anti-emetics), (2) Myelosuppression (low blood counts, infection risk), (3) Alopecia (hair loss - will occur), (4) Fatigue, (5) Doxorubicin - cardiotoxicity (monitor with echos), (6) Bleomycin - pulmonary toxicity (monitor PFTs, stop if lung toxicity), (7) Vinblastine - neuropathy, (8) Infertility risk (patient completed egg freezing 9/8 - retrieved 12 mature eggs, all frozen). FERTILITY PRESERVATION COMPLETED: Patient underwent ovarian stimulation, egg retrieval successful with 12 eggs vitrified (frozen). This gives her excellent chance for biological children in future via IVF. Patient relieved this completed before starting chemo. BASELINE TESTING: Echo normal (EF 62%), PFTs normal (will repeat after cycle 2 and 4 to monitor for bleomycin toxicity). Port placement scheduled Wednesday, first chemo Friday. Patient anxious but ready to start treatment. Parents will alternate staying with her during treatment weeks. Sister helping with appointments. Graduate program holding her position - can return when ready. Patient asking about prognosis - emphasized 80-85% cure rate, excellent prognosis compared to many cancers. Most patients complete treatment and return to normal life.

social_history_updates.fertility: Completed egg freezing - 12 eggs frozen successfully

clinical_timeline.chief_complaint: Mid-treatment assessment after Cycle 3 ABVD

started: Filgrastim (Neupogen) 300mcg SC day 3-10 after each chemo (for neutropenia)

new_acute: Classical Hodgkin Lymphoma Stage IIB on active treatment (C81.10)

procedures_ordered: Interim PET-CT after Cycle 4 (standard to assess response)
clinical_timeline.provider_note_snippet: COMPLETING CYCLE 3 OF 6 (C1D1: 9/22, C2D1: 10/6, C3D1: 10/20, C4D1: 11/3, C5D1: 11/17, C6D1: 12/1, currently day 7 post-C3). CLINICAL RESPONSE: EXCELLENT. B symptoms completely resolved - no more fevers, no night sweats, weight stabilized. Palpable lymph nodes in neck have dramatically decreased in size - largest node now <1cm (was 3.5cm). Patient feeling 'almost normal' between chemo cycles. TOLERANCE: Moderate side effects, manageable. CHEMOTHERAPY TOXICITIES: (1) Nausea - well-controlled with ondansetron and prochlorperazine, minimal vomiting. (2) ALOPECIA - complete hair loss (expected with ABVD). Patient wearing scarves/hats, handling well emotionally. Hair will regrow after treatment completion. (3) MYELOSUPPRESSION - Neutropenia requiring filgrastim support (Neupogen injections days 3-10 after each cycle to boost white cells). Mild anemia 10.4 (asymptomatic). Platelets adequate. No febrile neutropenia episodes. (4) FATIGUE - moderate, worse days 3-10 post-chemo, improves by day 14. Able to maintain some activities. (5) Mild peripheral neuropathy (vinblastine effect) - fingertip numbness, not bothersome. (6) No pulmonary symptoms (bleomycin toxicity monitoring). INTERIM IMAGING: Will obtain PET-CT after Cycle 4 (mid-treatment standard practice). If showing complete metabolic response (Deauville score 1-3), excellent prognosis. If persistent FDG-avid disease, may need to escalate therapy. Echo and PFTs also due - monitor for cardiopulmonary toxicity. PSYCHOSOCIAL: Patient coping well. Parents taking turns staying with her during chemo weeks. Friends very supportive - organized meal trains, rides to appointments. Patient doing some online coursework from PhD program (not full load but staying connected). Using lorazepam PRN for anticipatory anxiety before chemo (common). Connected with young adult cancer support group - very helpful. Patient expressing optimism - 'I can feel the cancer is gone.' Physical exam: No palpable lymphadenopathy. Port site clean. Alopecia. Otherwise well-appearing. Plan: Complete remaining 3 cycles of ABVD, restaging PET after cycle 4, radiation therapy to mediastinum after cycle 6 completion.

social_history_updates.support: Meal trains organized, friends very involved, parents alternating weeks

clinical_timeline.chief_complaint: End-of-treatment PET-CT results, radiation planning

new_acute: Classical Hodgkin Lymphoma, Stage IIB, in complete metabolic remission after ABVD (C81.10, Z85.71)

procedures_ordered: Radiation therapy 20 Gy to mediastinum in 10 fractions
clinical_timeline.provider_note_snippet: COMPLETED 6 CYCLES ABVD (last cycle 1/12/24). END-OF-TREATMENT PET-CT (2/10/24): COMPLETE METABOLIC RESPONSE (CMR). No FDG-avid disease anywhere. Deauville score 2 (uptake less than mediastinum, consistent with CMR). All previously involved lymph node stations show NO residual FDG uptake. Residual mediastinal soft tissue mass 4.2cm (decreased from 10.4cm) but NO FDG uptake - this is FIBROSIS/SCAR TISSUE, not active lymphoma. Spleen, liver, bone marrow normal. COMPARISON TO BASELINE: Baseline mediastinal mass 10.4cm SUV 12.8  now 4.2cm SUV 1.8 (background blood pool). Cervical nodes: baseline 3.5cm SUV 8.2  now not visible, SUV background. This is COMPLETE RESPONSE. INTERIM PET (after Cycle 4, 11/20/23) also showed CMR - patient has been in remission since mid-treatment. MONITORING TESTS: Echo: EF 58% (decreased from 62% but within normal range - doxorubicin causes small decrease, acceptable). No significant cardiotoxicity. PFTs: Normal, no bleomycin toxicity. ASSESSMENT: COMPLETE REMISSION. This is EXCELLENT outcome. With CMR to ABVD and planned consolidative radiation, cure probability >85-90%. PLAN: RADIATION THERAPY to mediastinal field (involved-field radiation therapy). 20 Gy in 10 fractions over 2 weeks (lower dose used when CMR achieved - reduces late effects while maintaining cure rate). Rationale: Bulky mediastinal disease at diagnosis (>10cm) requires consolidative radiation even with CMR. Reduces relapse risk. Radiation side effects: fatigue, esophagitis (difficulty swallowing), skin changes, long-term risks (secondary cancers, cardiac disease - will need lifelong cardiac surveillance). PHYSICAL EXAM: Well-appearing young woman. No lymphadenopathy. Hair regrowing (short pixie cut emerging). Port still in place (will remove after radiation completion). Patient thrilled with results, emotionally tearful with relief. Parents present, also emotional. Patient asking about returning to graduate program - cleared to return for spring semester after radiation completes (radiation won't be as debilitating as chemo). Discussed SURVIVORSHIP care: (1) Surveillance imaging every 3-6 months x2 years, then annually, (2) Cardiac surveillance (echo every 2-5 years lifelong due to doxorubicin), (3) Thyroid monitoring (radiation can cause hypothyroidism), (4) Secondary cancer screening (radiation increases breast cancer risk - need mammograms starting age 40 or 8 years after radiation, whichever first), (5) Fertility consultation when ready (has frozen eggs). Patient understanding will need lifelong medical follow-up but can resume normal life. Plans to finish PhD, career in clinical psychology. Grateful for support system that got her through treatment.

social_history_updates.education: Planning to return to PhD program spring semester

clinical_timeline.chief_complaint: Routine 3-month surveillance, new fatigue and mild cough

new_acute: History of Hodgkin Lymphoma in remission (Z85.71)

clinical_timeline.provider_note_snippet: 3-MONTH SURVEILLANCE after completing radiation (radiation completed 3/1/24). Patient back in graduate program full-time, doing well academically. Hair fully regrown, feels 'back to normal' mostly. NEW SYMPTOMS: (1) Fatigue x3 weeks - more tired than usual, napping daily (hadn't been napping). (2) Mild dry cough x2 weeks - non-productive, worse at night. (3) No fevers, no night sweats, no weight loss. PHYSICAL EXAM: No lymphadenopathy palpable. Lungs clear to auscultation. No hepatosplenomegaly. Port removed 3/15, site healed. LABS: ESR mildly elevated 32 (was 18 in February), LDH mildly elevated 245 (was 180). These are nonspecific but can indicate lymphoma activity OR inflammation from other causes. ASSESSMENT: Symptoms could be: (1) Post-radiation effects (fatigue, cough from radiation pneumonitis), (2) Viral upper respiratory infection, (3) RELAPSED LYMPHOMA (concerning given timing - only 5 months since treatment completion, 4 months since radiation). Early relapse (<12 months) indicates more aggressive/resistant disease. Ordered surveillance PET-CT (was due anyway) and CXR. If PET shows recurrent disease, will need salvage chemotherapy + autologous stem cell transplant (standard for relapsed Hodgkin). Patient anxious - 'I thought I was done with this.' Reassured most likely post-radiation inflammation but need to investigate. Results in 1 week.

social_history_updates.education: Back in PhD program full-time, doing well

clinical_timeline.chief_complaint: PET-CT results discussion

new_acute: Relapsed Hodgkin Lymphoma, early relapse (<12 months) (C81.10)

procedures_ordered: Biopsy of FDG-avid lymph node to confirm relapse
Consultation for salvage chemotherapy and autologous stem cell transplant
clinical_timeline.provider_note_snippet: DEVASTATING NEWS: PET-CT (7/15/24) shows RELAPSED DISEASE. Multiple new FDG-avid lymph nodes: Right supraclavicular node 2.4cm SUV 6.8, mediastinal nodes largest 3.2cm SUV 8.4, left hilar node 1.8cm SUV 5.9. Residual mediastinal scar tissue now shows FDG uptake SUV 7.2 (was SUV 1.8 in February - indicates viable tumor within scar). No extranodal disease. CXR: Widened mediastinum again. ASSESSMENT: RELAPSED/REFRACTORY HODGKIN LYMPHOMA. Relapse at 5 months post-treatment completion (10 months from starting ABVD) = EARLY RELAPSE. This indicates chemotherapy-resistant disease. Poor prognostic factor. NEXT STEPS: (1) Biopsy to confirm relapse (could be inflammation but PET findings highly suspicious). (2) If confirmed, SALVAGE CHEMOTHERAPY followed by AUTOLOGOUS STEM CELL TRANSPLANT (ASCT) - this is standard of care for relapsed Hodgkin. Typical salvage regimens: ICE (ifosfamide, carboplatin, etoposide) or DHAP (dexamethasone, cytarabine, cisplatin) x2-3 cycles, then if responding, proceed to ASCT. (3) ASCT involves: collecting patient's own stem cells, high-dose chemotherapy to kill all lymphoma cells (and normal bone marrow), then infusing stem cells back to rescue bone marrow. Hospitalization 3-4 weeks. (4) PR, PROGNOSIS: With salvage therapy + ASCT, 50-60% long-term disease-free survival for early relapsed Hodgkin. Without ASCT, relapsed Hodgkin is not curable. Patient and parents devastated, crying. Patient stating 'I can't believe I have to go through this again.' Explained this is setback but still curable with ASCT. Many patients successfully treated for relapsed Hodgkin go on to live normal lives. Will need more intensive therapy but goal remains cure. TREATMENT TIMELINE: Biopsy next week, salvage chemo starting late July/early August (2-3 cycles over 6-9 weeks), stem cell collection, then ASCT hospitalization likely October. Patient will need to take semester off again from graduate program. Discussed need for strong support system - this will be more intensive than first-line ABVD. Parents committed to being with her throughout. Patient asking 'why did it come back so fast?' - explained some Hodgkin lymphoma has inherent resistance to standard chemo, doesn't mean she did anything wrong. Scheduled urgent hematology-oncology and transplant consultations.

social_history_updates.education: Will need to take another semester off from PhD program

clinical_timeline.chief_complaint: Salvage chemotherapy planning, transplant workup

started: Ondansetron 16mg IV pre-chemo and q8h PRN

new_acute: Relapsed Classical Hodgkin Lymphoma, early relapse, chemotherapy-refractory (C81.10)

procedures_ordered: Port placement (new port - old one removed)
Stem cell mobilization and collection after Cycle 2 if responding
clinical_timeline.provider_note_snippet: BIOPSY CONFIRMED: Relapsed Classical Hodgkin Lymphoma, nodular sclerosis subtype (same histology). Reed-Sternberg cells present. CD30+, CD15+. Bone marrow biopsy: NO marrow involvement (good - limits transplant complications). TRANSPLANT EVALUATION COMPLETE: Patient is excellent candidate for autologous stem cell transplant. Cardiac function normal (EF 56%), pulmonary function normal, renal function normal, liver function normal. Performance status good (ECOG 1). Dental clearance obtained. SALVAGE CHEMOTHERAPY PLAN: ICE REGIMEN (Ifosfamide, Carboplatin, Etoposide) every 2 weeks x 2 cycles, then reassess response. If achieving partial response or better, will proceed to stem cell mobilization and collection, then ASCT. ICE is more intensive than ABVD: (1) All IV, given over 3 days (Days 1-3), (2) Higher nausea/vomiting risk (aggressive pre-meds), (3) More myelosuppression (will need filgrastim support, possible transfusions), (4) Nephrotoxicity (carboplatin, ifosfamide - aggressive hydration), (5) Neurotoxicity (ifosfamide - can cause confusion/encephalopathy, rare), (6) Hearing loss (carboplatin - high-frequency hearing loss possible), (7) Hemorrhagic cystitis prevention (mesna given with ifosfamide). TREATMENT TIMELINE: ICE Cycle 1: 8/19-8/21 (Days 1-3), ICE Cycle 2: 9/2-9/4, PET-CT: 9/16, Stem cell mobilization: late September (if responding), ASCT admission: October. STEM CELL COLLECTION: After Cycle 2 ICE, will give filgrastim (G-CSF) + plerixafor to mobilize stem cells from bone marrow into bloodstream. Apheresis (similar to dialysis) to collect CD34+ stem cells over 1-2 days. Goal: collect at least 2-5 million CD34 cells/kg body weight. Cells will be frozen until transplant. AUTOLOGOUS STEM CELL TRANSPLANT: High-dose chemotherapy (usually BEAM: carmustine, etoposide, cytarabine, melphalan) or CBV (cyclophosphamide, carmustine, etoposide) to eradicate all lymphoma cells. This also destroys bone marrow. Day 0: Stem cells infused back (like blood transfusion). Days 0-14: NADIR period - no immune system, high infection risk, require hospitalization in protective isolation. Expect: severe mucositis, diarrhea, nausea, requires IV nutrition/pain control. Day +10-14: ENGRAFTMENT - stem cells start producing new blood cells. Gradual recovery over weeks-months. PROGNOSIS WITH ASCT: 50-60% long-term disease-free survival for early relapsed Hodgkin. If disease relapses after ASCT, options include: brentuximab vedotin (antibody-drug conjugate targeting CD30), checkpoint inhibitors (nivolumab/pembrolizumab), CAR-T cell therapy (investigational), allogeneic transplant (donor stem cells, higher risk). Patient understanding this is much more intensive than first treatment. Taking full year off from graduate program. Parents both taking family leave from work to be with her. Sister coordinating care. Patient connected with transplant survivor support group. Financial concerns - transplant costs significant even with insurance. Social work helping with co-pays, travel/lodging assistance (if transplant at different center). Patient tearful but determined: 'I want my life back, I'll do whatever it takes.' Mental health counseling in place - PTSD from relapse common, anticipatory anxiety about treatment.

social_history_updates.education: Taking full year off from PhD program
social_history_updates.support: Both parents taking family leave, sister coordinating care
social_history_updates.financial: Concerns about transplant costs, social work involved

clinical_timeline.chief_complaint: Post-ICE Cycle 2, stem cell collection planning

started: Filgrastim 480mcg SC daily x10 days (for stem cell mobilization)

new_acute: Relapsed Hodgkin Lymphoma, partial response to ICE chemotherapy (C81.10)

procedures_ordered: Apheresis for stem cell collection - 9/23 and 9/24
clinical_timeline.provider_note_snippet: COMPLETED 2 CYCLES ICE (Cycle 1: 8/19-8/21, Cycle 2: 9/2-9/4). TOLERANCE: ICE much more difficult than ABVD as expected. Severe nausea first 5 days each cycle (controlled with high-dose ondansetron + dexamethasone + lorazepam). Profound fatigue. Brief ifosfamide-related confusion Cycle 1 Day 2 (resolved within 24 hours with hydration). Myelosuppression significant - nadirs ANC 0.8 (required hospital admission Cycle 1 for neutropenic fever, 48 hours IV antibiotics, resolved), hemoglobin requiring 2 units RBC transfusion, platelets requiring 1 unit platelet transfusion. No hemorrhagic cystitis (mesna prophylaxis effective). Weight loss 5 lbs (poor appetite, mucositis). Hair loss again (had regrown after ABVD). RESPONSE TO ICE: PET-CT (9/16): EXCELLENT PARTIAL RESPONSE. Significant reduction in FDG-avid disease. Supraclavicular node: 2.4cm SUV 6.8  1.2cm SUV 3.4. Mediastinal nodes: largest 3.2cm SUV 8.4  largest 1.8cm SUV 4.2. Left hilar node: not visible. Deauville score 4 (uptake moderately higher than liver but lower than baseline - indicates partial response, adequate to proceed to transplant). This is GOOD NEWS - disease is chemosensitive to salvage therapy, predicts better transplant outcomes. STEM CELL MOBILIZATION: Starting filgrastim today (Day +10 post-ICE Cycle 2, counts recovering). Will give filgrastim 480mcg SC daily x10 days to mobilize stem cells from bone marrow into peripheral blood. Plerixafor 24mg SC night before apheresis (enhances mobilization). APHERESIS scheduled Monday and Tuesday (9/23-9/24) at apheresis center. Large-bore catheter will be placed, blood circulated through machine to collect CD34+ stem cells, return blood to patient. Process takes 3-4 hours each day. GOAL: Collect minimum 2 million CD34 cells/kg (for 60kg patient = 120 million cells minimum). Typically collect 2-5 million/kg over 1-2 days. Cells will be cryopreserved until transplant. TRANSPLANT ADMISSION: Scheduled 10/7 for autologous stem cell transplant. Pre-transplant conditioning: BEAM chemotherapy (Carmustine Day -6, Etoposide + Cytarabine Days -5 to -2, Melphalan Day -1), Stem cell infusion Day 0 (10/13), Expected engraftment Day +10-14 (10/23-10/27), Discharge when counts recover and eating/drinking (typically Day +14-21). PATIENT STATUS: Physically exhausted, emotionally drained but hopeful about response. Parents with her daily. Sister managing logistics. Patient asking 'am I really going to get through this?' Reassured response to ICE is encouraging sign. Most difficult part still ahead (transplant hospitalization) but she's proven she can handle difficult treatment. Support team in place. Will see her Monday for apheresis.

clinical_timeline.chief_complaint: Post-ASCT Day +12, assessing engraftment

new_acute: Relapsed Hodgkin Lymphoma status post autologous stem cell transplant (C81.10, Z94.84)

procedures_ordered: Discharge planning when ANC >0.5 x 48hrs, platelets >20k, afebrile, tolerating PO
clinical_timeline.provider_note_snippet: AUTOLOGOUS STEM CELL TRANSPLANT COURSE: Admitted 10/7, BEAM conditioning Days -6 to -1 (10/7-10/12): Carmustine 300mg/m Day -6, Etoposide 100mg/m + Cytarabine 200mg/m BID Days -5 to -2, Melphalan 140mg/m Day -1. STEM CELL INFUSION DAY 0 (10/13): Infused 3.8 million CD34+ cells/kg (excellent collection, well above minimum). 'Rebirthday' celebrated with parents present. NADIR PERIOD (Days 0-12): As expected, SEVERE toxicities. (1) PANCYTOPENIA - all counts to zero by Day +3. ANC <0.1 Days +3 to +10. Now Day +12, ANC 0.9 (ENGRAFTMENT BEGINNING). Platelets requiring transfusions every 2-3 days. RBC transfusions twice weekly. (2) SEVERE MUCOSITIS - Grade 3 oral mucositis Days +5 to present. Cannot eat or drink, requires TPN (total parenteral nutrition) via central line. Severe mouth/throat pain requiring morphine PCA (patient-controlled analgesia). Using oral cryotherapy (ice chips), frequent mouth rinses. Mucositis expected to improve once engraftment occurs. (3) NAUSEA/VOMITING - controlled with ondansetron, minimal vomiting. (4) DIARRHEA - Grade 2, resolving. (5) FEVERS - low-grade fevers Days +3-7 (common during nadir, cultures negative, resolved with broad-spectrum antibiotics). No documented infections. (6) HEPATOTOXICITY - transient LFT elevation (expected with BEAM regimen), trending down. (7) WEIGHT LOSS - 10 lbs during hospitalization (fluid shifts, poor nutrition, expected). (8) FATIGUE/WEAKNESS - profound, bed-bound during nadir, now starting to ambulate with assistance. ENGRAFTMENT: ANC 0.9 today (Day +12) - first time >0.5 = ENGRAFTMENT! Expected timeline Day +10-14, right on schedule. Platelets 45k (still requiring transfusions until >50k sustained). Hemoglobin 8.2 (transfused today). INFECTION PROPHYLAXIS: Broad-spectrum coverage - levofloxacin (bacterial), fluconazole (fungal), acyclovir (viral, especially HSV reactivation). Will continue prophylaxis for 6-12 months post-transplant (immunosuppressed period). ISOLATION PRECAUTIONS: Strict protective isolation during hospitalization - private room, HEPA filter, masks for all visitors, no fresh flowers/plants, cooked food only. Will continue precautions at home for 3-6 months. DISCHARGE PLANNING: Patient eligible for discharge when: (1) ANC >0.5 x 48 hours (TODAY!), (2) Platelets >20k without transfusion x 24 hours (not yet), (3) Afebrile >48 hours (yes), (4) Tolerating adequate PO intake (not yet - still on TPN). Expect discharge in 3-5 days (Day +15-17). PATIENT STATUS: Physically debilitated but improving. Mucositis pain severe but manageable. Emotionally resilient - 'I know I'm through the worst part.' Parents at bedside daily (only 1 visitor allowed in room). Patient watching engraftment numbers closely, celebrating each ANC increase. PROGNOSIS: Successfully completing ASCT is major milestone. Post-transplant surveillance: Day +30 CBC/CMP, Day +100 PET-CT (critical scan - assesses remission status), then 3-month intervals for 2 years. Long-term risks: secondary malignancies (therapy-related MDS/AML 1-2% risk, solid tumors 5-10% risk over 20 years), infertility (likely permanent despite egg freezing - ovarian function suppressed, may not recover), cardiac toxicity (lifelong surveillance needed), pulmonary toxicity, hypothyroidism. But if Day +100 PET shows complete remission, 50-60% chance of CURE - never needing treatment again. Patient understanding this but focused on getting through immediate recovery. Planning discharge to parents' home (closer to hospital than apartment, better support).

social_history_updates.living_situation: Will discharge to parents' home for initial recovery period (closer to hospital)

archetype: Acute leukemia with life-threatening complications and molecular relapse
chief_complaint: Severe fatigue, bruising easily x3 weeks

ground_truth_correlations.description: Pancytopenia with circulating blasts indicating acute leukemia requiring urgent treatment
Achievement of complete remission with induction chemotherapy evidenced by bone marrow assessment
Neutropenic fever and sepsis during induction chemotherapy requiring ICU care
Molecular relapse detected by MRD testing before clinical relapse allowing early intervention

clinical_timeline.chief_complaint: Severe fatigue, easy bruising, bleeding gums x3 weeks
clinical_timeline.provider_note_snippet: 58M accountant presents with 3-week history of progressive fatigue, weakness, easy bruising. Reports multiple bruises on arms/legs without trauma, gums bleeding when brushing teeth, increased petechiae on lower extremities. Wife noticed increasing fatigue - 'sleeping 12 hours/night, can barely get through work day.' NO fevers, no night sweats, no bone pain, no lymphadenopathy. PAST MEDICAL HISTORY: Hypertension controlled on lisinopril, otherwise healthy. No prior cancers, no chemotherapy/radiation exposure, no toxic exposures. Family owns dry cleaning business but patient works in office (accountant), minimal chemical exposure. Never smoker, rare alcohol. PHYSICAL EXAM: Pale, fatigued-appearing but alert. Multiple ecchymoses (bruises) on extremities, petechiae on lower legs. Gingival oozing. No lymphadenopathy. Liver/spleen not palpably enlarged. No sternal tenderness. LABS CRITICAL: PANCYTOPENIA - Hemoglobin 7.2 (severe anemia), WBC 2.8 with ANC 0.6 (severe neutropenia - high infection risk), Platelets 18,000 (severe thrombocytopenia - bleeding risk). PERIPHERAL SMEAR: 15% CIRCULATING BLASTS (immature white blood cells - HIGHLY ABNORMAL, diagnostic of acute leukemia). LDH 680 (elevated - cell turnover), Uric acid 8.2 (elevated - tumor lysis risk). ASSESSMENT: ACUTE LEUKEMIA - clinical presentation + pancytopenia + circulating blasts = acute leukemia until proven otherwise. Most likely ACUTE MYELOID LEUKEMIA (AML) given age (peak incidence 60s), vs acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL, more common in children). This is HEMATOLOGIC EMERGENCY. Severe neutropenia puts at risk for life-threatening infections. Severe thrombocytopenia puts at risk for catastrophic bleeding (intracranial hemorrhage). IMMEDIATE ACTIONS: (1) Called hematology-oncology - patient being ADMITTED TODAY to oncology service, (2) Bone marrow biopsy scheduled for tomorrow (definitive diagnosis, identify AML subtype, cytogenetics/molecular markers guide prognosis and therapy), (3) Will need platelet transfusion (keep platelets >10-20k to prevent spontaneous bleeding), (4) May need RBC transfusion if symptomatic, (5) Urgent chemotherapy likely needed once diagnosis confirmed (AML progresses rapidly, days-weeks without treatment can be fatal). Patient and wife shocked - 'I thought I was just tired from work stress.' Explained this is serious blood cancer requiring immediate hospitalization and intensive chemotherapy, but many patients achieve remission and long-term survival with treatment. Called wife's phone as patient was being directly admitted from clinic. Lives with wife, 2 adult children (daughter in medical school, son in business). Wife very supportive, already contacting children.

social_history_updates.occupation: Accountant for family dry cleaning business
social_history_updates.family_history: Parents both deceased (father stroke age 78, mother dementia age 82), no family history of leukemia or other blood cancers

clinical_timeline.chief_complaint: Hospital Day 2, bone marrow results available

new_acute: Acute Myeloid Leukemia with normal cytogenetics, NPM1 mutated, FLT3-ITD negative, intermediate risk (C92.00)

procedures_ordered: Central line (PICC or tunneled catheter) placement
clinical_timeline.provider_note_snippet: BONE MARROW BIOPSY RESULTS (3/9): HYPERCELLULAR MARROW (90% cellularity, normal ~50% for age) with 68% MYELOBLASTS. Normal hematopoiesis markedly suppressed. DIAGNOSIS: ACUTE MYELOID LEUKEMIA (AML). FLOW CYTOMETRY: Blasts positive for CD34, CD117, CD33, HLA-DR, MPO - myeloid lineage confirmed. CYTOGENETICS: NORMAL KARYOTYPE 46,XY (no chromosomal abnormalities detected). MOLECULAR STUDIES: NPM1 MUTATION POSITIVE (favorable), FLT3-ITD NEGATIVE (favorable - absence of this bad mutation is good), FLT3-TKD negative, CEBPA negative. RISK STRATIFICATION: INTERMEDIATE-RISK AML based on: Normal cytogenetics + NPM1 mutated + FLT3-ITD negative = European LeukemiaNet (ELN) Favorable-Risk category. Good prognosis - 60-70% achieve complete remission with induction chemo, 40-50% long-term disease-free survival. TREATMENT PLAN: INDUCTION CHEMOTHERAPY - '7+3' protocol (standard of care for fit AML patients): Cytarabine 100mg/m continuous IV infusion x 7 days (Days 1-7), Daunorubicin 60mg/m IV push x 3 days (Days 1-3). GOAL: Eradicate leukemia, achieve COMPLETE REMISSION (CR) defined as <5% blasts in bone marrow, ANC >1000, platelets >100k. EXPECTED TIMELINE: Chemotherapy Days 1-7, Nadir Days 10-21 (severe pancytopenia, high infection/bleeding risk, most dangerous period), Bone marrow biopsy Day 14-21 to assess response, Count recovery Days 21-35 if CR achieved. Hospitalization 4-6 weeks typical. COMPLICATIONS TO EXPECT: (1) Severe myelosuppression - will need RBC/platelet transfusions, growth factors, (2) Neutropenic fever/infections (30-50% get serious infection during induction), (3) Mucositis (mouth sores, difficulty eating), (4) Nausea/vomiting, diarrhea, (5) Tumor lysis syndrome (cancer cells die rapidly, release contents - can cause kidney failure, cardiac arrhythmias), (6) Bleeding complications, (7) Prolonged hospitalization. SUPPORTIVE CARE: Allopurinol to prevent tumor lysis, antimicrobial prophylaxis (levofloxacin, fluconazole, acyclovir), aggressive transfusion support (keep platelets >10k baseline, >50k if bleeding; keep Hgb >7), IV hydration, anti-emetics. PROGNOSIS DISCUSSION: With intermediate-risk AML and favorable molecular profile (NPM1+/FLT3-ITD-), good chance of remission. If achieve CR, will need consolidation chemotherapy (high-dose cytarabine x 3-4 cycles) to maintain remission. Allogeneic stem cell transplant NOT recommended in first remission for favorable-risk AML (transplant has high mortality risk, reserved for high-risk or relapsed disease). Patient and family understanding severity - 'this is life-threatening' but also hopeful given favorable prognostic factors. Adult children both visiting daily. Daughter (medical student) asking detailed questions about treatment, prognosis. Patient stoic, stating 'I'll do whatever it takes.' Wife worried about business (patient manages finances) - assured team will help with disability paperwork. Starting 7+3 induction tomorrow after central line placed.

social_history_updates.work: Family helping manage business finances during treatment

clinical_timeline.chief_complaint: Hospital Day 14, post-induction Day 15, neutropenic fever

started: Vancomycin 1g IV q12h (adjusted for renal function)

procedures_ordered: Central line tip culture if line removed
Bone marrow biopsy when stable (assess remission status)
clinical_timeline.provider_note_snippet: CRITICAL ILLNESS - SEPTIC SHOCK. Patient developed fever to 103.2F at 2am (Day 15 post-induction). Initial evaluation showed profound neutropenia (ANC 0.0 - ZERO neutrophils), hypotension BP 98/58 despite 3L IV fluid bolus, tachycardia 118, tachypnea 24, O2 sat 94% on 2L NC. TRANSFERRED TO ICU at 6am for septic shock management. CLINICAL PICTURE: This is EXPECTED complication of induction chemotherapy - nadir period with complete absence of neutrophils leaves patient vulnerable to overwhelming infection. Developed PSEUDOMONAS AERUGINOSA BACTEREMIA (blood cultures positive, Gram-negative rod, common in neutropenic patients). Source likely GI tract (translocation of gut bacteria through mucositis-damaged mucosa). SEPTIC SHOCK: Meeting criteria for septic shock - infection + hypotension requiring vasopressors + lactate >2. Aggressive management: (1) BROAD-SPECTRUM ANTIBIOTICS: Cefepime (Pseudomonas coverage) + Vancomycin (MRSA coverage, especially if central line infection). Switched from prophylactic levofloxacin to therapeutic antibiotics. Added micafungin (antifungal - neutropenic patients at risk for invasive fungal infections). (2) VASOPRESSOR SUPPORT: Norepinephrine IV drip to maintain MAP >65 mmHg. (3) IV FLUIDS: Aggressive resuscitation (already received 5L crystalloid). (4) RESPIRATORY SUPPORT: Currently on 2L NC, may need escalation if worsens. CXR shows no infiltrates currently. (5) SUPPORTIVE CARE: Transfusions (platelets, RBC), nutrition (TPN - cannot eat due to mucositis), pain control. COMPLICATIONS: (1) Acute kidney injury - Cr 1.8 (was 1.0), likely from hypotension/sepsis. Adjusting medication doses. (2) Transaminitis - LFTs elevated, likely from sepsis, medications. (3) Severe mucositis Grade 4 - entire mouth/oropharynx with ulcerations, cannot eat or drink, severe pain requiring morphine PCA. Using magic mouthwash, cryotherapy. (4) Profound pancytopenia as expected during nadir. BONE MARROW STATUS: Cannot assess remission yet given clinical instability. Will perform Day 21-28 bone marrow biopsy once patient stable and infection resolving to determine if achieved complete remission. PROGNOSIS: Septic shock in neutropenic AML patients has 20-30% mortality. However, patient young (58), no other comorbidities, appropriate aggressive management initiated. If survives this acute infection and achieves CR, still has good long-term prognosis given favorable-risk disease. FAMILY MEETING: Wife and children at bedside. Very worried - 'is he going to die?' Explained this is life-threatening complication but team doing everything possible. ICU team excellent. Infectious disease consulted. Daughter (medical student) understanding severity. Patient intubated at 2pm due to worsening respiratory status (sepsis-induced ARDS). On mechanical ventilation, sedated. Family staying at hospital 24/7.

clinical_timeline.chief_complaint: Hospital Day 28, post-induction Day 29, extubated, awaiting bone marrow results

new_acute: Acute Myeloid Leukemia in complete remission (C92.01)
History of Pseudomonas septic shock, resolved (Z86.19)

procedures_ordered: Consolidation chemotherapy Cycle 1 scheduled 2 weeks after discharge
clinical_timeline.provider_note_snippet: REMARKABLE RECOVERY. Patient transferred out of ICU on Day 24 (after 9 days ICU care), extubated Day 23.
